Description:
The British Red Cross plays a vital role in emergency response, and the ongoing, ever-changing situation concerning the COVID-19 pandemic is no exception.

In times of crisis, we’re here to help people. We’re local and we’re global and we’ve been doing this for 150 years. Our network of incredible staff and volunteers means we are uniquely placed to reach people in fearful, uncertain times. 

But it’s the generosity of our supporters that enables our work to happen quickly and efficiently. We rely on your support to keep us going.
Title: SOUP's SOUP live at The Globe, Codicote

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Marie Curie is the UK’s leading end of life charity.  They provide frontline nursing and hospice care, a free support line and a wealth of information and support on all aspects of dying, death and bereavement.  In these uncertain times, raising money to help our local nurses makes such a difference. Every penny means they can provide more care – at home and in our hospices. The money we raise is desperately needed at the moment as coronavirus has forced the Marie Curie team to cancel many of their fundraising activities. 

Marie Curie is a charity that's very close to our hearts here at The Kitchen, as Kate explains: "My mum was diagnosed with stage 4 ovarian cancer in 2014.  She had around three years of treatment and also developed Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma before receiving a terminal diagnosis.  My sister and I were able to nurse her at home during her final illness and this meant so much to mummy and to us as a family.  In the final 3 weeks of her life we had support every night from the nurses at Marie Curie.  They didn't just care for mummy, they cared for us all.  They calmed our fears, allowed us to rest and provided so much comfort to us all during those lonely night-time hours.  They truly were our angels. 

So this Christmas at The Kitchen, we are holding a virtual Raffle Extravaganza to raise money for this wonderful cause.  

We have a great selection of 15+ prizes to be won, including hampers and vouchers from many of our local businesses. Along with each prize, each winner will receive a £20 Kitchen voucher as well.  These prizes will be shared on our social media pages over the coming days and the draw will take place on Tuesday 22nd December! 

Tickets are priced at 1 for £2, 3 for £5 or 6 for £10 and can be purchased in The Kitchen or by making a donation to this page - we will email you your ticket number(s) within 48 hours of entry.   Please remember to leave your name in the optional 'Your Name' box so that we can contact you should you be one of our lucky winners! You will still have the option to 'Hide' your name from public view should you wish. 

Thank you for supporting this wonderful cause,

The Kitchen Team xx
Title: Raffle Extravaganza in aid of Marie Curie

Description:
VIRTUAL ART EXHIBITION EXTENDED UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30TH -

And that means more time for us to raise more much-needed funds for the inspirational London's Air Ambulance, a charity providing lifesaving treatment for the capital’s most critically injured patients - fast. They've treated more than 40,000 seriously ill patients since 1989. They are true #londonheroes. You've probably seen their bright red helicopter racing across the London skies.

London's Air Ambulance rely on public donations and fundraising to keep flying.The 'A River Runs Through It' artists would love your support to help us beat the £1500 we raised at last year's show.


Here's how you can help us this year: VISIT, WIN PRIZES, SIGN UP!


VISIT OUR VIRTUAL REALITY OXO GALLERY and see our new London-art collections from until September 30th (www.ariverrunsthroughit.london), follow us on Instagram @ariverrunsthroughit2020 find out more). The artists will donate 10% of all sales to London's Air Ambulance.


DONATE TO WIN art and great London-themed prizes in our RIVER RAFFLE runnning throughout the show.

Just £3 per entry, with no limit on the number of entries- the more you enter, the better your chances of winning! We will automatically enter you in the raffle when you donate through JustGiving, one entry for each £3 donation - all we need is your email to let you know if you've won. 

Prizes include meals at London restaurants, trips on Thames Rockets  boats, vouchers for London theatres, training sessions, art work from  the artists and much more...                  


WATCH TABISH KHAN'S ENTERTAINING ART TALK AGAIN. Donate £5 and we'll send you the link to watch the talk again, with all profits going to London's Air Ambulance.

Join Londonist art critic, ArtCan Trustee and columnist for FAD magazine Tabish Khan to hear about "The Artist Who Ate A Corgi & Other Stories” - London’s history through Art. Tabish's talks are seriously popular, so make sure you book tickets as soon as you can.

And watch the very special PRIVATE VIEW again, hosted on Zoom by the Londonist's art critic Tabish Khan (@londonartcritic). Tabish takes you on a virtual VIP tour and chats to the artists. You'll also have an opportunity to hear about their incredible work from the London's Air Ambulance crew themselves. Visit www.ariverrunsthroughit.london to see the PV again.


This year's A River Runs Through It artists are LoveJordan, Ella Friere, Michael Wallner, Susan Bunn and Emma Reynolds. We're so grateful for any support you can give us and London's Air Ambulance.


ABOUT THE EXHIBITION

A River Runs Through It is an artistic celebration of London, hosted
by a collective of London artists every September, attracting more than 16,000 visitors to gallery@oxo in the last five years.

This year, due to the pandemic, we are hosting the show in a superb virtual reality Oxo gallery, alongside a fantastic programme of online talks, meet the artist and instagram events, short films with London heroes, our popular River Raffle, and more...

And that's where we really need your help.

Without the regular 6,000 visitors to a 'real gallery' this year we're
working even harder to attract more people to view the show and in turn raise even more money for London's Air Ambulance. We'd love to top last year's total of £1,500.

Find out more about the show and the programme of events @ariverrunsthroughit2020 on Instagram.

(Email: ariverrunsthroughit2020@gmail.com)

Big thanks from Jonny, Sam, Ella, Michael, Susan and Emma

We would love to see you all down at the Mazuma stadium the home of Morecambe football club. on Tuesday the 17th kick off is 5:30pm. There will be a raffle, hot food and the Bar will be open for beverages. Get yourself down to watch Neals Seals vs The Lancastrian squad. “The foodbank was there when we really needed it, it was an absolute lifeline.”We don’t think anyone in our community should have to face going hungry. Description:
The Hospice of St Francis helps 2,000 local people and their families, in Hertfordshire and Buckinghamshire, to live their precious lives well through improving symptoms, working with patients to achieve personal goals - helping them to feel safe - and anything from getting back to work, enjoying family time to walking the dogs again. The Hospice care takes many forms and their professional team plus dedicated, trained volunteers care for people with a wide range of illnesses including cancer, motor neurone disease, dementia, heart disease, lung disease and neurological illness.

The Hospice helps patients in their own home or here at the Hospice through 1:1 appointments or group sessions and on our Inpatient Unit.

They truly are a community Hospice, relying on your support to raise a majority of the over £5 million annually to fund our free care. Every penny is needed to do what we do.

Description:
For around 18 months Hannah has been planning to get her hair cut to donate to The Little Princess Trust, to be made into a wig for another child. Initially, Hannah had around the minimum amount of hair, around 7 inches to spare. However, she's waited and waited for it to grow so her donation will now be nearer to the preferred 12 inch length. Anyone who has ever brushed or combed Hannah's hair, will know how much patience and determination she has shown.  At last, the time has come and Hannah is ready to donate her hair. However we need to raise around  £380 to cover the cost of her hair being made into a wig  that can be given free of charge to a child who has undergone treatment for cancer. Every donation, regardless of the amount will help Hannah closer to her target. Thank you so much.

Description:
For 2020, Fudge Kitchen is delighted to be supporting the wonderful work of the Yorkshire Air Ambulance (YAA). Each year we select a chosen charity from a list of nominations put forward by our staff from all over the UK and dedicate a year’s fundraising to their cause. This year’s cause is like all of them, close to our hearts, but has special significance to the Assistant Manager of our Bath shop, Tia Hancy, whose Dad was rescued by emergency services, including the Yorkshire Air Ambulance after a farming accident in 2013.

The Yorkshire Air Ambulance is a lifeline for rural and less connected communities, being able to reach the scene of an emergency more quickly than traditional services. Yorkshire Air Ambulance (YAA) is an independent rapid response charity, which has carried more than 8,000 people in its nearly 20-year history. It needs to raise £12,000 each day to keep its two helicopters in the air and maintained - equivalent to £4.4 million each year.

Without any direct government funding, the only help the charity receives is through the secondment of its paramedics from the Yorkshire Ambulance Service NHS Trust. So, it is with great pleasure that Fudge Kitchen can support the work of this amazing charity throughout 2020.
Title: Fudge Kitchen Annual Charity 2020 - Yorkshire Air Ambulance

Description:
Thanks for visiting our fundraiser site. 

Imagine being homeless, having no option to self isolate or stock up on supplies, with many support services you were relying on closing down. Alongside homeless people there will be thousands more people who end up in food poverty, families who were relying on free school meals and those who have just been made redundant due to the crisis.

Since Friday 20th March Social Bite has re-purposed its entire organisation to create a nationwide food delivery service. Their kitchens, cafes and teams have been entirely re-deployed to produce and deliver food and supplies to those who need them most for the duration of this outbreak. They are working with more than 50 partners to ensure that food and essential supplies can reach the following people

- Homeless People

- Families that were relying on free school meals and now have no access

-Those who have been made redundant due to the crisis and are in food poverty

That’s why we’re supporting the campaign at Harajuku Kitchen. Through your support of our takeaway service we will be supporting many vulnerable people across Scotland.
Title: Harajuku Kitchen for  Social Bite 4000 meal a day fundraiser

Description:
Brewhouse & Kitchen at Poole, Bournemouth and Southborough in Dorset are support RNLI lifeguards this summer by hosting quiz and live music events, whilst raising vital donations for the RNLI. 

RNLI Lifeguards respond to the thousands of incidents that happen every year along coastlines in the UK and Ireland. Our lifeguards keep beachgoers safe by spotting the dangers and preventing accidents before they happen, as well as responding instantly if they occur. That's why providing our lifeguard crews with first-class training is vital. Lifeguards are qualified in lifesaving and casualty care, and are highly trained and fit. They maintain a level of fitness, which allows them to swim 200m in under 3½ minutes, and run 200m on sand in under 40 seconds.

But there's still training to be done. Your donation, supporting Brewhouse & Kitchen, will help fund this essential training, when visits to the south east beaches are higher than ever.

Thank you for your support.
Title: Brewhouse & Kitchen Supports RNLI Lifeguards

Description: I'm taking part in the official Dry January and raising money for Alcohol Change UK because alcohol does too much harm. You might have noticed some of that harm. Do you know someone who drinks too much? How does it affect their lives and the people they love? Or maybe you haven't thought about that much but still, alcohol harm is all around us. It affects the 200,000 children living with alcohol-dependent parents in England, the 1.2 million people admitted to hospital because of alcohol last year. One person dies every hour - affecting their family, friends and community. Please sponsor me to help change this. Let's help to change and save lives.

Description:
Hi Everyone!

I'm trying to raise some money to donate to Women's Aid this Christmas. This fantastic charity is so incredibly important to me and the work they do is invaluable. 

The organisation works to help women and children suffering from domestic abuse. 

Just some of the things they provide:

  • much needed support to women in need
  • campaign for changes to laws to help protect women
  • help survivors of domestic violence get back on their feet
  • conduct research 
  • training and qualifications to give support workers the tools required to help women in need. 

With the ongoing pandemic, their work is absolutely crucial with many women and children being forced to lock down with their abusers and being isolated even further from friends and family. 

Women's Aid provided support to me at a time when I needed it most and I am forever grateful. Now I am in a far happier and stable time in my life I would like to donate to the charity that helped me get here. 

Thank you,

Rosie
Title: Christmas Fundraiser for Women's Aid

Description:
As a lot of people know, I'm very proud of my long hair, but it's been pointed out on a number of occasions that the Little Princesses will benefit more from having it, so it's getting donated! On Friday 18th it's getting tied up, lopped off and put in an envelope to be made into a wig, and I'd love it if people were able to throw some pennies this way. I know it's been a hell of a year and no one is particularly flush at the moment, but anything will certainly help out!

----

When a child loses their hair to cancer or another condition, we'll be there with a free, real hair wig to help restore their confidence and identity. We won't stop until the research that we fund ends childhood cancer forever. Promise.Please visit us at www.littleprincesses.org.uk to find out how you can help us give young people back what cancer takes away.The Trust relies solely on the efforts of enthusiastic community fundraisers. We receive no formal funding. Please help to raise money for us so that we can help more families.
Title: Matthew's Have Yourself a Hairy Little Christmas!

Description:
Across The Body Shop at Home we are fundraising for Children on the Edge; to bring hope, life, colour and fun to children living on the edge of society.

Children on the Edge was sparked into life by Dame Anita Roddick over 30 years ago. Not long after this The Body Shop At Home began to support them. Children on the Edge supports over 15,000 of the worlds most marginalised children to realise their rights. In India, Uganda, Bangladesh, Myanmar and Lebanon they help create protective environments where children can thrive.

In 2021 our support can help Dalit children in India to access education, develop community activism and grow in confidence; helping to break the cycle of discrimination.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

An update:

When I pledged to complete this challenge, as a family we were living with the daily loss that Alzheimer’s Disease creates. To no longer be remembered by a loved one was cruel and heartbreaking. I couldn’t stop the damage that Alzheimer’s Disease was doing to my family but I decided that I could try to stop it happening to others. I pledged in April to raise as much as I could in honour of my lovely Father-in-Law, because although he may no longer have remembered who I was to him, I promised I would never forget who he still was to me. 

Sadly, but thankfully peacefully, ‘Dad’ passed away on 23rd June. I always knew that there was a chance when I pledged to complete this run in 4 weeks time that Dad wouldn’t be here with us to show him the medal I hope to earn. It makes my training sessions very emotional as I think of him as I run but I am determined, however slowly, to complete this 21km run in his honour on 12th September.

Thank you for any donation you can make, it will be hugely appreciated by so many who are, or will sadly one day be, sharing our heart breaking experiences. I hope for a day where no one suffers due to Alzheimer’s Disease. I would love to smash my target, that I never expected to almost reach, and support Alzheimer’s Research UK in their vital work.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and for all of your love and support since we lost ‘Dad’.

Jules xx

Instagram: @nrahmankitchen

https://www.instagram.com/nrahmankitchen

📍South London, SE11
• Level 2 Food Safety & Hygiene Certified
•Desserts, Snacks, Cakes, Cupcakes and more
•Collect and Delivery
•DM for Enquires📮

When you buy a cake from us, a set amount of proceeds will be dedicated towards saving the orphans so you're making an amazing contribution to bringing about change.

With SNP, help us to support Lonely Orphans as they provide essential support and care all over the world for orphans and those in dire need. There are over 153 million orphan children around the world. 

Every day, an estimated 5,700 more children become orphans due to war, natural disaster, poverty, disease, stigma and medical needs. SaveTheOrphans provides long term support for orphans and vulnerable children for 365 days of the year, allowing you to leave your legacy.


Focus areas:

Focused education for girls and boys | Re-housing for orphans and vulnerable families into adequate accommodation | Sustainable food security | Water and hygiene | Medical aid | - WAQF: Long term sustainability | Support with clothing and leisurely activities (+Eid Gifts)

Description:
Between June and October I will be undertaking 6 major challenges to raise money for both Motor Neurone Association & also MIND. I have sadly had personal experiences of both of these over the past few years. No doubt all of you who read this story will also have had experience of at least one of these illnesses unfortunately. These charities are essential to help with those suffering and also to fund much needed research into cures, support and well being. Please look at the following links for more information:

https://www.mndassociation.org/

https://www.mind.org.uk

My plan is to take on 4 * 100KM ultra hikes in The Lake District, Yorkshire Dales, Cotswold Way and the South Coast. In August myself and my good friend Ben Stoddart will be taking on the National 3 Peaks in 24 hours...assuming his feet have recovered from his monumental John O Groats to Landsend walk he successfully completed in March! My year of challenges will culminate with hopefully a successful ascent of Kilimanjaro at the end of September! Fingers crossed when I return in one piece a substantial amount of money will have been raised for these 2 essential charities.

Any support will be greatly appreciated and all donations will go directly to MNDA & MIND spit equally.

Title: Chris's Kitchs dryathlon

Description:
On the 16th September 2018 I will be setting off from Diss in Norfolk (UK) in my 'Big White Berlingo Car' on a long drive to Jerusalem.

I’ve booked one night in a hotel and a ferry ticket to Cherbourg and that’s it. The rest of the journey will be organised as I go along. My aim is to be in Jerusalem by the end of November and back home in the UK for Christmas (I’ve promised my family). That’s roughly 10,000  kilometres in just over three months. I’ve avoided a detailed plan in preference for spontaneity but the headlines are I will be travelling out through France, Italy, Greece and Turkey, and returning via the Balkans, then central and Western Europe. Unfortunately I will be forced to fly to Israel from Turkey as the land route either through Libya or Syria is too dangerous at the moment.

I will be generally sleeping in the back of the car, with
seats removed.  I use my mum’s old 1970 sofa cushion for a bed, and it serves the purpose well. Other than a map, a washing up bowl, a kettle, basic car repair kit and half a dozen changes of clothing that’s it. I’m doing everything on the ultra-cheap.

Why- 

Firstly it’s for myself. I don’t feel right unless I take on a few big trips a year especially now that I’m retired. But it’s also to raise money for my favourite charity 'Become' (http://www.becomecharity.org.uk/),which is the leading charity helping young people coming out of the care system and starting adult life. In my career as a psychiatric nurse I encountered many people for whom this transition had gone badly wrong. This is common. 'Become' works with care leavers to help them establish a firm footing, as they take their first steps toward independent living

What equips me for
this? -

 I am a sixty year old overweight, rheumatic retired psychiatric nurse with a lifelong love of independent travel using local transport, walking, hitch hiking or driving ordinary vehicles. 

There has been scores of these trips but just taking the best this hobby has taken me on over 10,000 miles worth of trips by motorhome around the USA. More recently I have travelled by long distance bus and ferry boat around Argentina (including Northern Patagonia) and the nearer parts of Uruguay. 

I spent a month travelling around India by train using second class carriages, that is those used by the poorest local people. Despite a general lack of fitness I’ve walked the first hundred miles of the Via Egnatia, a rough country track which follows a Roman road across Albania. Each spring for the last five years I have walked 100-200 miles  on the ancient pilgrimage route, the Camino Sangtiago de Compestela that runs from France to Galicia in North-Western Spain. 

During the 1980’s and early 1990’s I lived In South Africa and travelled extensively in neighbouring countries (Lesotho, Swaziland, Zambia, Botswana, and Zimbabwe).

I enjoy this kind of thing, and have been doing it
since I was a teenager. I do my best to be around local people, talk to strangers and find out how they live. I stay well clear of any tourist hubs and instead hop between smaller towns and immerse myself in local life for a few days. I’m the resilient type and tend to find a way of getting through or past obstacles.

On this trip I will be posting a daily blog and Facebook updates where ever possible. Sponsors will be able to follow my journey through these.

I have been very fortunate in my life but I've known many people who grew up in care, and then failed to find the help and support they needed when the time came to leave. Often they were ill equipped to cope alone and went on to have serious mental health or drug and alcohol problems. The charity 'Become' is all about helping such people with this transition. I've supported them for a number of years through personal donations , and have seen the quality of help they provide. Its really all about improving the life opportunities of people for whom things can...and  often go badly wrong  That's why I have chosen to undertake this trip to benefit 'Become'.

All the costs of travel are being met by myself and a separate network of sponsors. No money raised for 'Become' will come to me.

Title: Diss to Jerusalem and back in my Big White Berlingo Car

Description:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my page.

As some of you know, I turn 22 on the 21st September 2018. And instead of gifts, I am asking for donations through this page in support of Mind, the mental health charity. 

I have recently moved back to Suffolk, so see it as fitting that I specifically as for donations in support of Suffolk Mind.  

One of the many and most pressing struggles that people face are issues with their mental health.  This is especially high with young people, please see the below statistics that I have taken from: https://www.mentalhealth.org.uk/statistics/mental-health-statistics-children-and-young-people

 -  20% of adolescents may experience a mental health problem in any given year.

-  50% of mental health problems are established by age 14 and 75% by age 24.


-  10% of children and young people (aged 5-16 years) have a clinically diagnosable mental problem, yet 70% of children and adolescents who experience mental health problems have not had appropriate interventions at a sufficiently early age.

These statistics are incredibly scary, and as someone who relies on mental health services, I can honestly say that without charities such as Mind, the NHS would simply not cope.  The availability of mental health services in this country are very poor, with far more people reaching out for help than the system has availability for.  No one should have to face their mental health battle alone, and I want to help wherever possible.  

Mind will always hold a place in my heart, as without them I wouldn't have been/ be able to access the help that I need.  

I cannot thank everyone who has supported me over the last few years enough, as without external support I wouldn't be able to get better, support of friends and family, as well as mental health services, are vital to recovery. 

Thank you again, Suffolk Mind, and me, thank you from the bottom of our hearts for your support for better mental health. 

Emily

WE NEED TO SAVE ALL THE KITTIES!

 There are some horrible mean people don't like kitties..

That’s why we need the Cat Protection, an organisation that helps rescue and rehome poor unwanted kitties as well as educates people about cats and cats wellbeing. Both of my cute (-ish) kitties in my home are rescue cats and without organisations like Cats Protection both would have been left out in the wilderness to fend for themselves.

People like Cats Protection help find them, nurse them back to health and rehome them while not asking much in return. Because of them I have two little floofy madams that bring warmth, character and sometimes mice into our home.

Description:
A group of us from the Immunology Research Unit at GSK and Immunology Business Development group have got together to run the Cambridge Half marathon. We haven't run a half marathon for a very long time or for some it's our first time. It's a new challenge for 2022 and we would be REALLY grateful if you could sponsor us to raise money for Save the Children. GSK will match all the money we raise. 

Thank you very much in advance!


Save the Children supports children to explore a world of possibility. They support children to learn, grow and become who they want to be.

A lot can get in the way of education. But from Cambridge to Congo, a love of learning is universal. Children know it's key to a world of possibilities. Save the Children ensures children keep learning no matter what. Whether recovering from natural disasters, facing violence, or at risk of child marriage. And in the UK, they are improving early years learning and keeping childcare costs on the political agenda. They’re working around the world to help children keep learning, making friends, and building their futures.

Their hunger relief and nutrition programmes help millions of people every year. Around the world, their teams provide counselling, breastfeeding support, malnutrition screening, vitamin supplements and cash transfers.

More children are surviving their early years than ever before. That is still too high a number and now rising inequality, pandemics and the climate crisis are set to make it worse. Save the Children is determined to change this. We're pressuring governments and working with global partners to improve health for millions. Every day, our doctors, nurses and health teams are saving lives in hard-to-reach communities around the world.

We want to make sure all children get the care they need for the best possible start in life.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit the Companion 40 for 40 Club fundraising page. 

Sue Ryder Wheatfields appealed towards the end of last year for 40 Leeds businesses to sign up to commit to helping them raise £40,000 for the hospice in 2018, which is their 40th anniversary year.

It costs £11,000 a day to run the hospice, which has 18 beds, 271 staff and volunteers and eight hospice shops. They have cared for a total of 40,000 patients.

Companion's target is to raise £1,000 this year from a number of fundraising activities; we're planning a Bake Off competition, a Halloween tombola, a Yorkshire 3 Peaks Challenge and loads more!

£1,000 could pay for:

  • a syringe driver to give constant pain relief for patients
  • a bed for two days of inpatient care for a hospice patient
  • 10 individual visits by community nurses

Please help us to reach our fundraising target and support the Wheatfields team in their fantastic work.

Description:
This year, instead of Christmas presents we’re asking friends and loved ones to help us raise money for the Fetal Medicine Foundation and the amazing research and training they provide into areas such as early diagnosis of fetal abnormalities and prevention of stillbirth.

This year we experienced first hand the incredible work they do and we just want to show our gratitude by giving something back.

If you’ve found yourself here you will know that on 23rd July this year I gave birth to our daughter Cassi. You’ll also know that our Cassi wasn’t meant for this world and I gave birth to her knowing this. I can’t begin to explain what it feels like going through labour, for the first time, knowing your child has died before their life has truly begun. Our journey was one of utter joy then devastating sadness. I still find it difficult to even put into words. But what we do know is that we desperately want something good to come out of all of this and that’s why we’re asking, you to help us raise money for the Fetal Medicine Foundation.

So, if whilst you’re buying presents, cards and food treats for Christmas you can spare a few of your pennies for this amazing charity we would be immensely grateful.

Much love Naomi and Simon 💕

PAPYRUS is the national Charity for the Prevention of Young Suicide.

Suicide is the biggest killer of young people under the age of 35 in the UK, in 2018 over 1800 young people took their own lives. PAPYRUS provides confidential support and advice to young people struggling with thoughts of suicide, and anyone worried about a young person through their helpline, HOPELINEUK.

Every £5 raised can help pay for a life-saving contact to HOPELINEUK. Your donations really are lifesaving, thank you

Title: April's Random Act of Kindness Day

Description:
Hello!

My name is Sam, and I'm [trying to reframe my coping mechanisms away from someone who may describe themselves as] an alcoholic.

In September 2019, I took part in a 24 hour hike across the Scottish Highlands to fundraise for Mind. I smashed it, and raised £1145 (https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/sam-kitchen2).

Since then, people have asked me what my next challenge is. Could train and run a marathon, travel to other parts of the earth to experience extreme temperatures and weathers, could go volunteer in other countries to build shelters and do general good people things.

Or, I could learn how to sit with my own company, regardless of how much I want to block out the realities of life. I think I'd rather climb Mount Everest, thanks.

I'm fundraising for Samaritans as we all just need someone who can listen to us, sit with us where we are without judgement, help us find acceptance and continue to live life to the best of our ability.

This wont be easy. I'm fully expecting to slip up from time to time. Please stick with me through this, friends - I'm gonna need you!

Love, Sam xxx

Description:

My plan is to complete 1,000 miles on my motor cycle in under 24hrs in memory of my brother and sister-in-law and while doing so raise funds for Wakefield Hospice who looked after my brother and sister-in law.  The world has gone through a lot of late but we must not forget people and places like Wakefield Hospice who rely on donations.

After lockdown I will ride the Northern clockwise route of the Iron Butt Association to Wick and back in Northern Scotland. For verification I will take photographs at the six check points on departure, Birch Services M62, Fort William services , Wick services , Edinburgh services and Berwick on Tweed A1 services and on arrival back home, of both mileage, receipts and time from all petrol station stops. All in line with the Iron Butt Association rules. I will pay for my my own fuel while completing the challenge and whatever I spend on fuel I will match to Wakefield Hospice.

No date has been set as I will wait for a dry weekend and then set off on my challenge very early on a Saturday morning returning early hours of Sunday morning.  

If lockdown continues the challenge will run into 2021.

Thank you for your support.

Andy Kitchen.
Title: Andy's page

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Title: In Memory of Neal Kitchen

Description:
Ava and Nellie have decided that they wanted to create a new club called The Pink Club, and as part of this they want to raise money for charity.

Their first fundraiser is for the Springhill Hospice and they aim to walk, run, cycle, 4 miles every day for 40 days, between them. So, in total 160 miles!! In the middle of winter they're going to battle the weather too!

They have also said as part of the club, that they would like to do a raffle for everyone that donates with kids and adult prizes (prizes to be confirmed)

Springhill Hospice provides care & support to people with a life limiting illness & their families. Springhill passionately believe that everyone should have access to the best care at the end of their lives. To help achieve this, Springhill's expert team work night and day in people’s homes and at the Hospice to offer specialist care. Springhill also support people emotionally, provide practical information & help them maintain their independence and dignity.
Title: Ava and Nellie's 4x40

Description:
Thank you for visiting my Justgiving page. I have decided to raise money in memory to help more families get the specialist dementia support that they desperately need. 

Dementia UK's Admiral Nurses work alongside people with dementia, and their families: giving them one-to-one support, expert guidance and practical solutions. The unique dementia expertise an Admiral Nurse brings is a lifeline. It helps families to live more positively with dementia in the present, and to face the challenges of tomorrow with more confidence and less fear.

Thank you so much for helping pay tribute to my loved-one by helping other families facing dementia.
Title: My collection In Memory of Dorothy Littler

Description:

I will be biking and walking with my family 100miles duing the month of May.

Please donate to help other people.

Thank you from Benjamin.

Description:
Our vision is a world free from the fear of heart and circulatory diseases. We raise money to research cures and treatments, so we can beat heartbreak forever.

Find out more about what we do here: https://www.bhf.org.uk/what-we-do/who-we-are

We have helped improve and save the lives of many people with heart and circulatory diseases. But these conditions still affect millions of families.

With challenges like Dechox, we hope to raise funds to take on the challenges in the research of heart and circulatory diseases.
Title: My Dechox Fundraising Page

Description:
I've been growing my hair to donate for what feels like forever! Please sponsor me for the Big Chop on Saturday 2nd April. Financial donations are needed to cover the costs of providing and fitting the wigs.

When a child loses their hair to cancer or another condition, we'll be there with a free, real hair wig to help restore their confidence and identity. We won't stop until the research that we fund ends childhood cancer forever. Promise. Please visit us at www.littleprincesses.org.uk to find out how you can help us give young people back what cancer takes away.The Trust relies solely on the efforts of enthusiastic community fundraisers. We receive no formal funding. Please help to raise money for us so that we can help more families.
Title: I'm donating my hair to the Little Princess Trust!

Description:
As I’m sure everyone is, we are heartbroken watching what is unfolding in Ukraine and we wanted to do something, anything, to contribute here at Macmillans Kitchen and Benview Garden Centre.  We have decided to cycle (virtually) from Kyiv to Lviv 468km as the crow flies. No mean feat!!! 

On 25th March, David, Kellie, Tracey and Gavin will be the main cyclists, the four of them rotating shifts with two indoor bikes. We’ll also have an extra ‘hot bike’ where we’d love a hand from staff, customers…anyone!!!  There’s ALOT of km to cover!!

Benview Garden Centre will be lending a much needed hand with a raffle and space for our cycle.  It will be very much a blue and yellow themed day 🇺🇦

Intense conflict in Ukraine is threatening the lives and livelihoods of civilians across the country, causing hundreds of thousands to flee. Homes have been destroyed or are unsafe to live in. Essential services have been hit. Families have been separated. People have been injured. Lives have been lost.DEC charities and their local partners are working to meet the immediate needs of all people fleeing with food, water, medical assistance, protection and trauma care.

£30 could provide essential hygiene supplies for three people for one month

£50 could provide blankets for 4 families to keep them warm

£100 could provide emergency food for two families for one month
Title: My DEC Ukraine Appeal Fundraising Page

Description:
For the people that know me, know that in 2012, on the 14th of November, I was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes at the age of 12. A lot of people don’t know a lot about diabetes, the different types, the affects it has on people suffering with it, the seriousness of it. 

So, I'm going to be swimming 22 miles towards a healthier me, and a better future for people living with diabetes. And also to raise awareness about type 1 and type 2 diabetes. If you would like to support me by donating, sharing, liking, or even joining me on my journey then I would greatly appreciate it.
Title: Beth

Description:
Alzheimer’s Society is transforming the landscape of dementia forever.Until the day we find a cure, we will create a society where those affected by dementia are supported and accepted, able to live in their community without fear or prejudice.

We are holding a Cupcake Day at Cup & Kitchen to raise as much as we can! So come on down, buy a cake or two, drink coffee and smile knowing you’ve made a positive impact!

Description:
In June Nick, Marcus and Chris will be completing the Way of the Roses Coast to Coast Cycle.  This challenging route stretches from Morecambe to Bridlington and spans 170 miles!!

All proceeds will go towards the amazing Ronald McDonald House Charity.

Ronald McDonald House Charities UK provides free ‘home away from home’ accommodation to families with children having treatment in hospital. Our Houses offer much more than just a place to stay; they provide family activities, peer support, respite, and many other services. This means that families can be by their child’s bedside in a matter of moments, whilst maintaining a degree of normal life with reduced emotional and financial strain.We help over 6,000 families each year and now, more than ever, we need your support. Thank you.
Title: Gourmet Kitchen Coast-to-Coast Cycle

Description:
This year at Rock Kitchen Harris we’re supporting Leicester youth homelessness charity The Y.

Not only does The Y work to help vulnerable young people across the city, but they also operate Leicester’s oldest theatre, giving wide access to the arts and offering many performers their first stage.

This is a really tough time for the charity, so to help them raise funds we’ll be swapping our beds for a night under the stars as we hold a sleep out on Friday 11th September.

We hope to raise a lot of money for The Y, and get an insight into the struggles that young homeless people face.

You can read more about The Y's work at https://www.leicesterymca.co.uk/

Follow our social media channels for updates before, during and after our event:

https://twitter.com/rkhleicester

https://www.facebook.com/RKHLeicester

Description:
Bakes4orphans helps orphans during Ramadan and beyond. 


When you buy a cake from us, a set amount of proceeds will be dedicated towards saving the orphans so you're making an amazing contribution to bringing about change.


With SNP, help us to support Lonely Orphans as they provide essential support and care all over the world for orphans and those in dire need. There are over 153 million orphan children around the world. 


Every day, an estimated 5,700 more children become orphans due to war, natural disaster, poverty, disease, stigma and medical needs. SaveTheOrphans provides long term support for orphans and vulnerable children for 365 days of the year, allowing you to leave your legacy.


Focus areas:

Focused education for girls and boys | Re-housing for orphans and vulnerable families into adequate accommodation | Sustainable food security | Water and hygiene | Medical aid | - WAQF: Long term sustainability | Support with clothing and leisurely activities (+Eid Gifts)

Description:
We're very proud to see how many people ordered the Compassion Burger from @cleankitchenuk. We raised over £300 in profit to help end the cruel practices of factory farming. Founder Mikey Pearce wants to take that to £1000. He's a huge fan of a challenge so will be running 100KM in 7 days, starting tomorrow. We will be so grateful for any contributions, big or small. 💚🐑

We are thrilled to announce our first charity partner, Compassion in World Farming. We understand and respect that everyone is on their own journey to a more plant-based diet and want to be inclusive as a brand by helping people along the way. That’s why we believe the work that CIWF does is so important. CIWF’s main goal is to bring an end to the cruel nature of factory farming and encourage more compassionate treatment of animals.

We have created The Compassion Burger, inspired by our Clean Kitchen Club mascot, Pumpkin, a rescue sheep that lives on Verity Bowditch's mum’s animal rescue farm! 🐑

The Compassion Burger is a plant-based burger available to order on Deliveroo, with all profits going to CIWF. 🍔💚
Title: Clean Kitchen Compassion Burger

Description:
As we return to hosting in-person book clubs, we are inviting our book club members to our table for a special lunch along the pages of Sweet Darusya by Ukrainian author Maria Matios. We'll be taking care of the food and invite everyone to consider donating to the #CookforUkraine fundraiser in support of Unicef. 

We will be cooking favourites from Olia Hercules' Summer Kitchens with a menu tailored for spring, we'll be breaking bread together and eat it with some delicious smetana as we learn about Ukrainian literature and delve into the life and work of author Maria Matios. 

Here's a little bit more about the book and its author to inspire you to read Matios' work and support the work of Ukrainian authors: 

Maria Matios is a Ukrainian poet, novelist, cookbook writer and official. She was born in the village of Roztoky in the Bukovyna region, and resides in Kyiv. She authored 12 volumes of fiction and poetry, including the novel Sweet Darusya (2003), and the collections of stories titled The Short Life (2001) and Nation (2002). Her first poems were published when she was fifteen years old. In 1992 she published her first prose in Kyiv Magazine. Maria Matios bases her books on the unique experiences of her family, whose roots go back as far as 1790. She was the winner of the "Book of the Year 2004" prize and of the Taras Shevchenko National Award in 2005 (for Sweet Darusya). In the 2014 Ukrainian election Matios was re-elected as a deputy in the Ukrainian parliament. 

Sweet Darusya follows the story of Darusya, a woman who doesn’t speak and lives in the countryside, with her family and the locals in her isolated village in the Carpathian Mountains on the Ukrainian-Romanian border. The origins for Darusya’s affliction are revealed through this compelling tale, which won the Taras Shevchenko National Prize, one of the most prestigious prizes in Ukraine.

The Salmon Pink Kitchen is a book-club and culinary community that reclaims the kitchen as a political space.
Title: Join us and UNICEF in fundraising for Ukraine

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
Many of you have called, emailed or messaged to ask about how we are coping with COVID-19 and the impact it has had on our organisation. Firstly, let me say thank you for the outpouring of support we've received. It's always a heart-warming feeling to know that we have so many incredible supporters. 

Last week, in light of the Coronavirus, we made the difficult decision to offer a takeaway-only food service to guests rather than their usual sit-down meal. As most of you know, we take a huge amount of pride in the fact that we offer not just a warm meal to our guests, but also a safe and warm space off the streets for them for the hours they're with us. As we considered the health risks we decided that it would be prudent to only offer a takeaway food service for the foreseeable future.

Absolutely any donation will have a huge impact on our services. Thank you for helping us support the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate in London!
Title: Soup Kitchen London Emergency Appeal

Description:
Support Children at Risk of Food Insecurity!

We are master’s students from the School of Management at the University of Bath raising awareness of food insecurity and funds to combat this issue. Households that are ‘food insecure’ mean that they cannot guarantee sufficient quality or quantity of food.

Our efforts will be directed to support Kitchen Social, a leading holiday food provision programme in this space.

Founded by an independent charity, the Mayor’s Fund for London, Kitchen Social gives children and young people a safe place to socialise, learn and get a free, healthy meal. The programme helps to alleviate the financial strain on families that comes with accessing food and childcare activities during the school holidays. Long school breaks, without the support that young people need to thrive, is one of the drivers of educational attainment gaps between young people from different socio-economic backgrounds. Food insecurity over the school holidays can lead to learning loss, lower self-esteem, and weight gain. Poor nutrition and social isolation not only affect a child’s wellbeing but also impacts physical and mental development, thereby perpetuating the cycle of poverty.

Kitchen Social has a city-wide network of over 100 local community organisations including schools, adventure playgrounds, and youth clubs that provide nutritious food and fun activities. In response to the pandemic, Kitchen Social also created "Take and Make" – a recipe box series designed to engage children at home with their families. These boxes contain ingredients for four portions of nutritious food, alongside recipe cards and online video tutorials.


What we'll deliver:

 ・Raise funds for Kitchen Social’s Take and Make boxes so they can be distributed to young people during the Christmas break, providing opportunities for children to learn new skills and cook together with their parents

・Contribute to Kitchen Social’s Christmas Grant Activities where families can attend a Christmas party in their local area, access food, and take part in entertaining activities


Why it's a great idea:

Covid-19 has caused the number of families living in food insecurity to rise. A recent Mayor’s Fund for London survey revealed that 75% of families reported having less money for food. Many do not qualify for government support.

Kitchen Social is stepping up to support more local community organisations during school holidays. Take and Make boxes help to ease the pressure that some parents feel outside of term-time. It is a fantastic way to support a child's wellbeing and encourage young people into the kitchen to learn about ingredients, try new skills and cook nutritious food with families and friends.

We will be running an online cooking class to fundraise for this project. Engaging with two nutrition-based TikTokers and a chef who will be doing a live cook along. These activities aim to:

・Contribute towards Christmas holiday funding, providing young people with activities, social engagement, and a delicious meal during the Christmas break

・Fund ingredients for Take and Make boxes

・Provide children at risk of food insecurity with Take and Make boxes

More information about our online cooking class is available at the link below!!!:

https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/online-cooking-class-with-nigel-thompson-teawithmrt-tickets-165170827391?keep_tld=1

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
The American Soup Kitchen (SK) on Tottenham Court Road has been providing food to the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate everyday for over 30 years. With the recent COVID-19 related lockdown it witnessed a collapse in its corporate funding. We would like to assist them in raising some money as a result. 

At a time when most other soup kitchens have had to close, the SK has been serving approximately 150 meals per day. They have implemented social distancing measures such as take away meals and ensuring 2 metre distancing between Guests. 

The SK has adopted the government’s guidelines for charities in the work that it does to protect its staff, volunteers and beneficiaries.

For instance the SK has taken steps to protect its staff, volunteers and guests by enforcing social distancing using ground markers and security personnel and by insisting upon the use of sanitizers provided and by asking guests to move on once they’ve collected their hot and cold food parcels.  

We are writing to ask for your help by way of £15 per month for the next three months - so £45 to help see the SK through the worst of this global crisis. Our aim is to get 100 funders on board in this way which will help cover monthly running costs for about 50 Guests until corporate funders return post the lockdown. Over the last ten years we know many of you have supported the fantastic work of the SK, sometimes as volunteers and at other times through donations of food and clothing.  

A massive THANK YOU from us and from the SK ! 

 Paliwal  & Maru Families
Title: Soup Kitchen London Emergency Appeal

Description:
So my beard has been with me since time began and many of you have said in the past "im gonna cut it off in your sleep".  Well here's your chance to help my beard earn some money for a worthy cause.

I have been volunteering at Soup Kitchen in Newbury for the last few years and i cant think of a better cause to enable them to support the most vunerable in society.  Not just the homeless, anyone who comes through the door.

So in the words of Bob Geldoff “Give us your f***ing money” ;-)ill

I'll be cutting it off on my shift at the Soup Kitchen on Nov 21st.

From 12th November 2018, the Newbury Soup Kitchen is division of the HAVEN (West Berkshire) homeless charity. It is a voluntary organisation providing help and support to the Newbury homeless, rough sleeper community and those less fortunate than others. The primary operation is a friendly drop-in centre for vulnerable adults who perhaps have mental health issues or are just lonely. All are greeted with hot food and drinks every Thursday evening. A warm welcome awaits people who wish to socialise, find support and enjoy a hot meal.
Title: Tom's Bin the Beard for the Soup Kitchen

Description:
Maggies Dundee needs your help now more than ever. 
 
Were here giving the best possible support to people with cancer and their families at this incredibly difficult time. 
 
We have one to one phone, skype, facetime and email support. Our online community, run by psychologists, cancer support specialists and benefits advisors, is there to answer questions directly and post daily blogs on how to cope with self isolation or treatment changes. You can join our online kitchen table and chat to others in the same position. 
 
Everything we do depends on your kindness
 
We will always be there for people with cancer but we need you alongside us.
Title: Maggie's Kitchen Table Day's page

Description:
I'm hosting a Kitchen Table Day on Sunday 3rd April to support people with cancer as I was unfortunately diagnosed with stage 4 Bowel cancer in October last year that has spread to my liver and lymph nodes. Maggie’s Manchester has been a god send to me and my family supporting us along the way through a very difficult time.

I wanted to raise awareness so that others that are going through a cancer can utilise Maggie's centres and their wonderful support. 

Maggies is a wonderful charity that supports so many.
Title: Maggie's Kitchen Table Day 3rd April 2022

Description:
I'm hosting a Kitchen Table Day to support people with cancer.  

My daughter Leanne has unfortunately been diagnosed with stage 4 Bowel Cancer which has spread to her Lymph Nodes and her Liver. It is inoperable and has no cure and has devastated our family and friends.

Any donation however big or small would be massively appreciated 

Thanks for your support

Title: Maggie's charity raffle

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
I have been volunteering at the American International Church Soup Kitchen since 2015. In 2015 a ‘busy day’ counted at around 30 people for lunch. It now caters for well over 100 people per day. 

The Soup Kitchen doesn’t just cater for the homeless. It is also their for the needy, hard up, those who are struggling and even the lonely. 

Due to the pandemic and shielding, I haven’t been able to volunteer like I used to. It was a regular fixture for me, going without fail every month. As such, because I haven’t been able to help out in person like I would normally do, I have decided to run the Hackney Half Marathon to raise some money, give back and help out in another way 🙂.

Title: Khrystal's 5 ALIVE SOUP KITCHEN

Description:
This is our story..

We are a group of young people taking part in NCS's Summer Scheme. Part of our social action, is to pick a charity and raise awareness, funding and get our hands dirty by giving back to our community.

We have chosen Southport Soup Kitchen as we find their work so important within our local community.

We are hoping to raise money, raise awareness and collecting the essentials like shampoo/sanitary products/soap/food/water/gloves/socks and other things that will make life a little easier for the homeless and people struggling, in and around Southport. 

Any donations are encouraged, we are grateful for every single penny and we hope that you will encourage your family and friends to help us reach our fundraising goal. 

(If you'd like to give us tinned good and long lasting foods, you can drop them off at Southport Community Church Southbank Road, and label the bag with 'Catch 22, Southport group 4' and it will be added to our collection. 

Thank you for your time.

Title: Soup  kitchen helping those in need

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
Many of you have called, emailed or messaged to ask about how we are coping with COVID-19 and the impact it has had on our organisation. Firstly, let me say thank you for the outpouring of support we've received. It's always a heart-warming feeling to know that we have so many incredible supporters. 

Last week, in light of the Coronavirus, we made the difficult decision to offer a takeaway-only food service to guests rather than their usual sit-down meal. As most of you know, we take a huge amount of pride in the fact that we offer not just a warm meal to our guests, but also a safe and warm space off the streets for them for the hours they're with us. As we considered the health risks we decided that it would be prudent to only offer a takeaway food service for the foreseeable future.

Absolutely any donation will have a huge impact on our services. Thank you for helping us support the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate in London!

Title: Soup  kitchen helping those in need

Description:
This pandemic has shone a light on areas where more support is needed within the community, and the UCKG HelpCentre has endeavoured to do more by providing support to help those in need. One of the ways the HelpCentre achieves this is by the use of Food Banks and Soup Kitchens within the community.

We currently run the UCKG Soup Kitchen in Leeds, which serves ready-made meals and soups to locals every Saturday of the year. We have seen the importance of this work in recent months, receiving over 1,223 visits, making use of the service since the turn of the year, attendance of which continues to increase weekly.

However, though we are currently operating as a Soup Kitchen, we do not have an actual kitchen where meals can be freshly prepared for locals on the premise, limiting the number of people we can reach out to and serve. While we are glad that we have been able to help many in the area of Leeds, we would like to offer more to the community and those in need as a result of these difficult times; building a new Kitchen would allow us to do just that.

 This is where we need your help. To fully operate as a Soup Kitchen, we need to raise the funds that will cover the costs of the works and installation that will be done. Therefore, we kindly ask for a donation to contribute towards the total cost of the £20,000 we would need to do this work.

 We believe that together we can reach this target and help those in the community who are in need. We appreciate the consideration and hope that you will be able to support the local community in this project. Thank you in advance for your kind donations!

Description: From 12th November 2018, the Newbury Soup Kitchen is division of the HAVEN (West Berkshire) homeless charity. It is a voluntary organisation providing help and support to the Newbury homeless, rough sleeper community and those less fortunate than others. The primary operation is a friendly drop-in centre for vulnerable adults who perhaps have mental health issues or are just lonely. All are greeted with hot food and drinks every Thursday evening. A warm welcome awaits people who wish to socialise, find support and enjoy a hot meal.

Title: Winter Soup

Description:
Hello again everyone and also to those who supported this cause last year! The fight goes on for the people in our community especially the community outreach project of the UCKG HelpCentre. Last year we were able to accomplish what we never imagined, thanks to your generous support! A huge thank you for that! 

With your donations last year, we were able to open 2 additional soup kitchens, 6 additional food banks with 2 more to be opened. Where an average of attendance of 3,850 visits per month, alongside a total visit of 38,031! 

Additionally, our hospital outreach scheme were able to donate to 26 hospitals, with the Night Angels (who at night go to feed the homeless) were able to have 323 runs! 

I am truly grateful for donations made to support this cause. 

However we press on forward to accomplish much more! I do believe BIGGER is BETTER!!

With our soup kitchen vastly growing and reaching out to individuals and families across the community, we need your help once more. 

I kindly ask of you to make a generous donation so that once more we can feed families, help the hospitals, feed the homeless, and keep our 24hr Helpline running! 

Together we can accomplish BIGGER and BETTER!

Title: LSU Action Soup Kitchen 2020 - 2021

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
At Tonic, we launched the Pay It Forward campaign as a direct response to October 2020’s parliamentary vote which denied food to children in need, during the school holidays.

It felt like such a juxtaposition to the abundant hospitality scene we know, to think of these children, hungry through no fault of their own, and we simply had to do something about it.

The Tonic Pay It Forward campaign is simple: for every single complimentary meal we receive or arrange, we donate a meal for someone hungry. And we pledge that it will remain an integral part of this business for as long as we are running. We have huge ambitions for this - we want to raise as much money as possible and connect the disparate food experiences in London and beyond.

So far, together with our community, we have raised over £6,000 including £1,283 for Magic Breakfast, £2,675 for The Trussell Trust, £1,740 for Made in Hackney and over £1,500 for Carib Eats - and this is just the beginning!

Now, as of 19 July 2021, we are fundraising for The Soup Kitchen to help support them in their mission to provide crucial support to homeless and vulnerable people throughout London. Not only do The Soup Kitchen supply healthy and nutritious food, but provide critical mental health support, clothing, and friendship for the homeless, elderly, lonely and vulnerable.

Such is the power of our community, and the calibre of people and companies we partner with, that alongside our donations many clients, journalists and friends have been energised by the initiative and joined us too. There are too many to thank personally, but to all of you committed to creating positive change with us, you are wonderful.

Title: AWC 2021 The Soup Kitchen Holiday Appeal

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
WHY The Soup Kitchen – A charity based on Tottenham Court Road, providing free meals, clothing, toiletries and a sense of belonging to nearly 150 friends each
day. Earlier this year NatWest employees helped support the charity, involved
in activities such as cooking, preparing takeaway bags and serving food and
drinks to their guests.

WHY Cycling – Over the lockdown many have taken up physical activities, with cycling
being one of the more popular sports. With colleagues returning back to the
office, we thought this would be a fantastic opportunity for a day out cycling
in the Surrey hills.

About the Soup Kitchen https://amchurch.co.uk/soup-kitchen/

Established in 1986, The Soup Kitchen is a resource for the homeless, elderly, lonely and vulnerable in London. We provide free meals, clothing, toiletries and a sense of belonging to nearly 150 of our friends each day. Additionally, we recently launched Europe’s first on-site mental health drop-in centre within a soup kitchen to address our guests’ mental health needs. With the help of hundreds of volunteers each year, we aim to provide a nutritious meal in a safe and warm environment that welcomes everyone.
Title: NatWest Treasury Charity Cycle

Description:
The last few months have seen immense suffering and hardship from storms and flooding. However the outbreak of the Coronavirus has quite literally changed everyones lives and turned society upside down.
However, The Salvation Army is resolute and strong and just as we did in the Spanish Flu pandemic, and during the bombing and the Blitz we will carry on, doing what we can to support people and communities  in the ways that we can, within the Government guidelines.
In true Salvation Army Spirit, our greatest strength is our flexible, responsive local presence. Right now, each of our 650 corps and community centres will know exactly what the most effective things are to do. We are not just responding to the virus impact in one or two ways, but dozens and dozens of different ways, from food banks to counselling, from supporting NHS isolation units to checking up on people who are living alone
Please give what you can to enable us to help as many people as possible!
Title: Parkhead Corps's East Glasgow Soup Kitchen & Food Banks

Description:
This Boxing Day, Chris, Barny and Cathy will be hitting the streets of Central London with a makeshift soup kitchen in the back of 'The Bongo', to give out hot soup, Christmas snacks, doggy treats and blankets to the homeless.

On Boxing Day we'll be mobile around central London in the morning and then pitching up near Trafalgar Square, if you wish to support us on the day please come along with your warm heart and whatever wish you wish to donate.

We've had lots of generous donations from friends already, including soup, blankets, dog food, sleeping bags and serving equipment. Thanks so much to everyone who's helped us so far!

For those of our friends who are simply too far away and would like to help please donate what you can to Crisis.

And for those only able to support in spirit, we would be grateful if you can share our plight with your friends to help raise awareness of the homeless crisis this Christmas.

Thanks so much,

Chris, Barny & Cathy

X
Title: Boxing Day Bongo - A Mobile Soup Kitchen #xmaspresent

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On the 30th of May 2021 I will be doing another soup challenge! I’m so committed to finding a CURE for DIPG that I shall be doing this EVERY YEAR on what would of been Kyles birthday! I hope I’m not still doing it when I’m 90! There has been no change to the treatment for DIPG since astronaut Neils Armstrong daughter died aged 4 almost 50yrs ago . These children are told to go make some memories. The only treatment they’re offered is radiotherapy and given some steroids. Their life spans range  from 3 months to 12months . 

Kyle Morrison will be forever 9 , he should have been following his dreams . Kyle wanted to be a police officer. Sadly Kyle left a huge hole in the hearts of his mum Victoria , little brother Tyler and grandmother and all who knew him . DIPG is a monster , it affects their ability to walk , to see , to eat and eventually breathe . It’s leaves a child trapped in their body in darkness fully aware and in agony. There is no treatment for DIPG, just radiotherapy and steroids. Families are told to make memories. Kyle never got to make memories because the world went into lockdown. Trials all over the world , where also put on hold , so the scientists could find a cure for Covid. We need a cure .

Action for Pulmonary Fibrosis (APF) is a growing community of patients, families, researchers and healthcare professionals striving to find a cure for pulmonary fibrosis so that everyone affected by the disease has a better future. We provide personalised support to patient and families - and raise awareness of pulmonary fibrosis through campaigning, fundraising and education. We are also committed to funding research to improve the quality of life for people living with pulmonary fibrosis today and tomorrow.

Pook's story is available on my website : www.thetruthaboutipf.  

He fought a brave and far too short battle against this disease.
Title: Pook Zanetti's Birthday

Description: Annabel is 8 years old and has a big heart for helping others. She came to me when she was about 3 or 4 years old, upset that boys and girls were getting sick because they didn't have what she took for granted. Since then she has sent some pocket money but wants to do more. The soup and sweet lunch is her idea and she is organising it. She truly believes that clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.
Title: Annabel's Soup and Sweet Lunch

Description: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation's research and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

Title: Eva & Eliza's Birthday Fundraiser

Description:
We are a local, growing driving school, and we're hosting a Mock Test Day. This is where full licence holders can visit us, and one of our friendly instructors will take the full licence holder out for a 30 minute mock driving test, assess their driving, and provide feedback and results at the end. 

We're really interested to see how many full licence holders still have the skills to pass their driving test - whether they've been driving for 1 year, or 15 years. 

We'd love for this to be a fun, informal event, where people can put their driving skills to the test, whilst raising money for such a deserving, hard working, local charity. 

We hope to see you there!

Title: DKM Driving's Mock Test Day

Description:
No matter how much you do, physical activity is good for your body and mind. Being active is one of the five ways to well being and adults should aim to be active every day.

To motivate our team to keep moving and raise much needed funds for Southport Soup Kitchen, we have signed up to a workplace step challenge. Pledging to each take 300,000 steps throughout the month of March. That is MILLIONS of steps together.

The "Soupie" haven't been able to accept donations of food for many months due to the ongoing Coronavirus pandemic. This has made their efforts to support local people and their families even more difficult. Monetary donations are now absolutely vital in order to provide vouchers for those in need to buy food and essentials from local supermarkets.

We sincerely appreciate all donations that will help Southport Soup Kitchen continue to provide warm food, a place to rest and good company for the disadvantaged of Southport.

A daily brisk walk can boost your energy, lift your mood and make everyday activities easier. Walking is simple, free and one of the easiest ways to get more active and become healthier. 

More information on the health benefits of walking can be found by following the link below. It also has resources for walks with wheelchairs and walks with buggys as well as guides to exercising indoors for those who aren't able to get out and about.


Walking for health - NHS (www.nhs.uk)

Title: Steve's Kintbury St Marys 2021/22 Charity Campaign

Description:
Thank you to everyone on our team for choosing to give up doing Secret Santa in order to help others less fortunate and support the work of a local charity.

This charity helps deal with homelessness by providing food to those in need. Homelessness is something that is very close to my heart.

When I was 21, not many people know this but I nearly found myself out on the streets. Had it not been for the help of a friend then I would have had nowhere to go and may not be where I am today. No one should ever have to face this situation in modern society. 

We have now opened this up to anyone who also wants to donate towards this amazing charity, every little helps!
Title: Our Not-So-Secret Santa

Description:
As a Youtuber I have spent the last 18 months raising over £60,000 for various charities.

Three charities from the County of Cambridgeshire were offered to my viewers and they voted to raise money for the Peterborough Soup Kitchen whilst we are in the Cambridgeshire area. 

You can read the full story at:

https://thetraveltroll.uk


You can follow my journey on Youtube at:
https://www.youtube.com/c/TheTravelTroll 

Please give generously and help to make a difference to people less fortunate than ourselves this winter.

Thank You.

Description: Jan 2017 Meryl set up Newbury Soup Kitchen. It is a voluntary organisation providing help and support to the local homeless, rough sleeper community and those less fortunate. During the Covid-19 crisis, they provide about 300 meals a week. This is done by way of delivery. The food is cooked, bagged up in individual ‘grab bags’ which have a hot vegetarian meal, fruit, snack, drink and homemade cake or biscuit. Newbury Soup Kitchen works solely on food supermarket/public donations, public monetary donations and grants. They cannot do what we do without this. Alexandra and Gabriella feel strongly that they want to help the homeless and those struggling for food at this time.

Description:
Hey Guys! 

So you know this ongoing crisis of homeless starving people and people living below the poverty line, it really brings me down seeing how the numbers have risen, especially here in Peterborough. 

After thinking about the silly ways I spend money, like buying £16 boxes of teabags and how crazy that seems when so many people would rely on that to feed themselves,

I thought I'd actually do something about it and I shall be living on £1 a day for two weeks and all the donations will be going to our local soup kitchen here in Peterborough. 

So tonight when you're eating dinner, or opening some wine or just reaching for a quick snack thinks about hose who can't.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit the JustGiving page for IOE&IT Band Aid.

This Christmas we want to raise funds for Peterborough Soup Kitchen to help support the incredible work they do all year round, with Christmas always being a particularly challenging time for the charity. 

Based in our home city, Peterborough Soup Kitchen is a local charity for homeless and disadvantaged people from in and around Peterborough.​

Their aim is to ensure that anybody who turns up at our serving van receives hot soup, food and drinks throughout the year, whatever the weather conditions. 

To raise much needed funds and support these efforts, the IOE&IT team will be picking up their microphones (and musical instruments) to remotely record a special version of the Band Aid festive classic - Do they know it's Christmas.

We'll make sure the end result is distributed far and wide so whether you're encouraging us to get our vocal chords ready for action or if you've seen the video and were (inevitably) impressed, please do donate to this great cause.

Description:
What is the Waterloo Foodbank?

The Waterloo Foodbank exists to provide 3 days of nutritionally balanced emergency food to local people in crisis.

They work with frontline care professionals to identify those in need. 

All food given out is donated by the public

ABOUT THE FOODBANK

They exist to ensure that no one in Waterloo goes hungry.

For people on low incomes, a sudden crisis – redundancy, benefit delay, illness or even an unexpected bill – can mean going hungry. Every day parents skip meals to feed their children and people are forced to choose between paying the rent or eating.

Since their launch at the end of 2011 they’ve given away over 90 tonnes of food to over 11,000 people in need, including over 4,000 local children.

They are part of The Trussell Trust’s UK-wide foodbank network, and together they provide food to thousands of people nationwide every year. The Foodbank is hosted at Oasis Playspace, Chapter 1 and St George the Martyr on behalf of South Bank Churches.

Help us to support the fantastic work of the Waterloo Foodbank!
Title: Oasis Waterloo FoodBank - Soup-A-Stars

Description:
Love never fails. 
Coronavirus impacts all of us. But love unites us all. 

As this virus spreads across the world, love rises up in response. 

Youve already shown incredible kindness to your neighbours. 
Now is the time to reach out to your neighbours both near and far. 

Your love protects. From storms, from drought, and now from coronavirus. 
Your love protects our global neighbours battling the spread of this illness. 
Your love protects. With soap, clean water and medical supplies. 

By supporting us this Christian Aid Week you can reach out and protect more of your neighbours today. 

For over 70 years, we've been standing with the poorest of our neighbours, with people of all faiths and none, to stand up for dignity, equality and justice. Let's stand together with our neighbours near and far.
Title: Christian Aid Week 2020

Description:
Intense conflict in Ukraine is threatening the lives and livelihoods of civilians across the country, causing hundreds of thousands to flee. Homes have been destroyed or are unsafe to live in. Essential services have been hit. Families have been separated. People have been injured. Lives have been lost.

DEC charities and their local partners are in Ukraine and across the border in the neighbouring countries. They are working to meet the immediate needs of all people fleeing with food, water, medical assistance, protection and trauma care.

£30 could provide essential hygiene supplies for three people for one month

£50 could provide blankets for 4 families to keep them warm

£100 could provide emergency food for two families for one month
Title: My DEC Ukraine Humanitarian Appeal Fundraising Page

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

ALL our amazing volunteers, who cook, cut , peel, pack, and drive are walking to raise much needed funds to enable us to expand this growing initiative, supplying “GOODY BAGS” every Friday to over 150 elderly, alone, unwell, recipients all over Essex. 

Each bag contains a large pot of homemade Chicken soup, a savoury dish, a homemade cake, a pot of fresh fruit salad, a challah bread, serviette,  fresh fruit, all Made With Love ❤️ on a Thursday from Loughton Synagogue! and bringing a wonderful smile to each and every one of our recipients who wait for us to arrive each week. 

Every donation given will enable us to continue and expand our facilities to accommodate our ever growing numbers. 

We thank you so much! ❤️
