Description:
Thank you for supporting my fundraising in aid of the DEC Ukraine Humanitarian Appeal. 

I'm Nicole and I run the multi award-winning The Kids' Kitchen - an online kids' cooking school. I'm going to be running a free online cooking class making a traditional Ukranian poppy seed cake on SUNDAY 13 MARCH 10-11AM.

[the replay will be in the Facebook group if you can't make it live]

Get your superstar chefs in the kitchen and have some fun cooking along with me, learning a new recipe and raising as much money as possible for Ukraine.

There are 3 ways to help raise money:

-             Pay for the class – donate instead of the usual class fee

-             Hold your own bake sale – and donate the proceeds

-             Donate anyway!

What you need to do:

- Join the special Facebook group to watch the class live/replay (link below or type in "Kids Cook for Ukraine with The Kids' Kitchen" on Facebook) 

https://www.facebook.com/groups/293394659411080

- Download the recipe and kit list and get in the ingredients. You should have everything other than poppy seeds!

- Attend the class this Sunday 13 March at 10am or watch on replay in the Facebook group

- Donate! 

- Spread the word – PLEASE share this link with all your friends, school mums, any groups or PR contacts you know that can help. 

As one of my regular Cook Club mums said, it’s a lovely way of letting the kids feel they can do something to help at the same time as having some fun and learning about another culture and trying a new recipe. 

And the more people that join the class, the more money we can raise. Everyone is welcome - it's a great family activity to do together.

Nicole x

Description:

Background - I've been dj-ing for 20 years, I've done the bars, clubs and festivals and nowadays (aside from my day job) I do private events, corporate and weddings and since the lockdown began I've been doing LIVE streaming DJ sets from my kitchen, which have quickly turned into a weekly show dubbed the Saturday 'Kitchen Rave'.

Last year I set out to achieve a life long DJ ambition of DJ-ing NON STOP for 24hrs and not only did that happen, but I managed to raise nearly £20k (with Gift Aid) for our beloved NHS!

This year I am celebrating 40 yrs of age and for that I've decided to challenge myself even further, set the bar even higher and put my energy and love for music into a ridiculous 40hr DJ set to raise as much money as possible for the incredible charity - MIND!!

PLEASE JOIN ME ON THIS EPIC JOURNEY!

Starting at 8pm Friday 19th March I will DJ my way through 40hrs of music finishing mid-day Sunday the 21st!! The number of genres is too long to list but I will publish these on my Facebook page soon so you can tune in to whatever you like!

Most importantly - this is a one time event and I want to make the biggest impact possible so please dig deep and give as generously as you can! 

Thanks for all your support so far. Please get involved, share and tag away as many people as you can and if you know anyone in the MEDIA/TV/NEWS business please give them a nudge and let's make this event go national!

ENJOY!

Description:
The People's Kitchen try to provide 1 new pair of boxer shorts and 2 pairs of socks to each of our friends on a weekly basis. At the moment, stock of these items is really low and the charity are seeking urgent donations.

Socks are the items that are donated the least, mainly because we all tend to wear these until they have holes and then we throw them away! Friends of the Kitchen are often out on the streets in all weathers and don't have the facility to dry damp footwear which can lead to blisters, sores and infections.

Please donate whatever you can so we can help The People's Kitchen provide new items to those most in need.

Thank you for your support.

Title: Anisa's Studio North Kitchen Table Day

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We recently attended and Anti Poverty evening in Kirkcaldy and I was shocked to find out that Kirkcaldy foodbank alone spend £8000 per month on food! Run by 100 volunteers. More than one third of those who receive support from Kirkcaldy foodbank are children. 8650 food parcels per month are given out from Kirkcaldy foodbank. These figures left me feeling very sad and that I wanted to do something to help.

I know many of us have our kitchen cupboards packed so full that if we simply cleared away the tins of soup we aren't going to use, the pasta packets that we have 4 of along with the excess boxes of cereal we have never looked at. That we together could help these people and help Kirkcaldy foodbank, even if its a drop in the ocean for them.

That is why I am asking you all to please donate £5 worth of food from your cupboards, or £5 from your purse/ wallet.

In return, your name will be entered into our draw to win a kitchen deep clean inc oven clean to the value of £80. Once the draw ends I will pull one name from a hat and that lucky winner will receive this offer. You can enter as many times as you like. So go on, have that kitchen clear out and see just how much you have that can be donated, I bet its a lot more than you think!!!

Thank you in advance,

Cara and all the team at Domestic Matters x
Title: Domestic Matters Kitchen deep clean give away

CharityName: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

The Kitchen and Management teams at Beefeater Marsh Mills are joining in the 2.6 charity challenge. We always try to do what we can to help those who need the help the most. We have done it successfully in the past so we would like to set another challenge.

We are going to ride, walk, run, hop and skip the distance from our Restaurant to Great Ormond Street Hospital and back in 10 days. That's a total of 419 miles!  The team will be recording their contributions on Strava. 

As we always say: we are Team Awesome. We are confident that we will smash our challenge and hopefully raise lots of money to to help save children's lives and support their families. 

Every donation makes a huge difference. Especially during these unstable and challenging times for everybody, it is so important to show that together we are stronger!
Title: Marsh Mills Kitchen Team Virtual Long Distance Race

Description:
Emily is a qualified Nordoff Robbins Music Therapist. Like many people over the last year she has had to move most of her work online. Despite the pandemic, Emily has provided remote music therapy sessions, group sensory music sessions and most recently a SNAP online choir. She is also part of the team bringing Radio SNAP to Facebook Live every Friday morning at 9.30am on SNAP's Facebook page (link below). Families have told SNAP that these sessions are often the highlight of their week!

As if all this wasn't enough, exemplary Emily is also supporting SNAP with an incredible 24-hour Disco!

"I have been involved with SNAP charity for nearly 12 years now, and it holds a very special place in my heart. I love our Friday Facebook Live sessions each week and when I accidentally suggested that I should do a 24-hour Kitchen Disco fundraiser, I initially thought - what have I done?!

However, literally seconds after I thought what better way to show my support for all of the fantastic work that SNAP does, than to offer what I love most in the world - music!

Music is such a lifeline for me and for so many people, especially over the lockdowns this past year. Our online sessions have enabled people to come together through their love and enjoyment of music, so why not offer this for 24 hours!!

I will be holding our Kitchen Disco live from The SNAP Centre along with the wonderful Karen and Dale from 9:30am on Friday 5th March, all the way through to 9:30am on Saturday 6th March, singing and playing requests from people who are able to support and join us on the SNAP Facebook page. I will also have some fun musical games, as well as some special friends who will pop by to sing or play us a song to keep us going!

A 24-hour Kitchen Disco is going to be hard, so if you are able to sponsor us in advance or donate on the day we would really appreciate it. Join us on the SNAP Facebook page as well to give us some words of encouragement - we're going to need it!!!"

This really is an incredible challenge and we can not wait to watch it live on SNAP's Facebook page - https://www.facebook.com/SnapCharity 

Every donation is hugely appreciated and will go a long way towards helping SNAP continue to be here for Essex families who have a child or young person with any special need or disability. Thank you for helping make this possible. 

If you'd like to find out more about SNAP (Special Needs And Parents) please do visit:

  • Our Website:  https://www.snapcharity.org/ 
  • Our Impact Page which has a great video:  https://www.snapcharity.org/our-impact/
  • Our Facebook page:  https://www.facebook.com/SnapCharity
  • Or read our latest SNAP Matters Magazine:  https://www.snapcharity.org/about/snap_matters_magazines/

Description:
As we begin to ease out of lockdown in the UK, a lot of people who will be excited to go back to the pubs, shops, gym etc as they reopen but not everyone is able to get out and about. 

The UK government has stated two visitors are allowed in care homes to reunite with loved one which is why I've designed this Sharing is Caring Treats Box, priced at £12. 

100% of profits from each Sharing is Caring box sold will be donated to Age UK, one of the leading UK charities helping to give support to older people who at this time can't get out and about. 


Donating to this page will help Age UK to continue providing vital services that offer companionship, advice and support for older people facing later life alone.

Description:
In 2018 and 2019, I joined thousands of other volunteers at Crisis at Christmas as a catering volunteer at one of their London day centres. The afternoon shift cooked up hundreds of portions of hot mains and puddings every evening and I peeled more potatoes than I ever thought I could.

In 2020, Crisis at Christmas was much different. For safety reasons, there were no day centres and only a minimal number of experienced volunteers. Guests needing shelter were hosted in hotels with external catering provided. 

2021 marks the 50th Crisis at Christmas and this year there will be some day centres running, with hotel accommodation for those in need of shelter. It still wont be the same scale of operation we saw back in 2019, but it's a step forward in being able to support more guests again.

So on 27th, 28th and 29th December, me and my trusty potato peeler will be back, cooking up breakfasts and a hot lunch.This year a place at Crisis at Christmas costs £29.06 and with your help I'd love to raise enough funds for ten spaces. Your donation will help provide:

~ Accommodation
~ Hot meals, including a Christmas dinner
~ Befriending scheme
~ Year-round access to training and education services
Title: Crisis at Christmas Catering Volunteer 2021

Title: Poppy and Lillie's 24 hours in a kitchen without leaving!!!

Description:
I'm running the London Marathon in October with my sister, 10 years since we last ran for one of our wonderful friends charity Fight For Sight.  Emma set up The Tommy Salisbury Fund in 2005, when her then 5 year old son Tommy was diagnosed with Choroideremia, a rare genetic eye condition.  This would mean that Tommy's sight would start to deteriorate from his late teens until total blindness later in his life.  Rather than taking this news and being beaten by it the family set about raising money to find a treatment and hopefully a cure.  

Emma along with the support of all her friends and family have so far raised over £600,000 and this money has funded a trial which Tommy himself has been lucky enough to have been a patient... one of his eye's has been treated and currently there has been no further deterioration of his sight.

There is still work and research to be done to make this trial available to all Choroideremia suffers.

Please help us raise money to help fund this cutting edge research and treatment... your money can actually help cure this which is just amazing.

Every £5 donation will be a ticket to win one of our beautiful wooden and persex art easels, perfect for children of all ages worth over £350.

The lucky winner can choose the colours and have it personalised, delivery included UK Mainland Only, the winner will be picked at random on Monday 22nd February and announced shortly after.

Multiple tickets can be bought, for example £20 will get you 4 tickets with all money going direct to the charity.

Thank you for your support and good luck xx

Description:
Hello everybody, my name is Myles. I might only be little but I wanted to do my bit to support a great charity who have helped me and my family a lot. As some of you may know, I was born with a cleft palate and got my new mouth in March of this year. I am really enjoying staying at home with my Mummy and Daddy and have recently taken up walking (with the help of some new wheels). My plan is that each day, I will complete 26 laps of the kitchen island. I will do this for 26 days. I will take requests for songs to do my walking to, and Mummy and Daddy will share some clips of my efforts on here (first one available to view now: Mummy picked the song to get us started. See https://youtu.be/X_LyLxVUdkE).

My Mummy wanted you to know that this fantastic charity are in real danger of collapse due to the pandemic. CLAPA works with our local cleft team to provide feeding equipment, support, as well as being the national voice for the progression of cleft care. And we want to do our bit to help.

Mummy also wanted me to let you know that she is cooking 26 new recipes for me to eat and will share progress for anyone that is interested. She hasn't set a time limit for this as she thinks she's got enough on, what with the lockdown and everything.

We know it's a difficult time, but if you are able to support our event, we would really appreciate it, and know this fantastic charity would too.

With much love,

Myles Arthur Kelly xxxx

(almost nine months)

#twopointsixchallenge #CLAPA #1in700 #Mylesaroundthekitchen

Description:
The Wildheart Trust is based at the Isle of Wight Zoo on the east coast of the island. It's most treasured aim is to give safe and loving forever homes to big cats and other exotic animals which have been abused in circuses and in the pet trade. 

The Wildheart Trust has recently provided a forever home for five tigers from their former circus life and, more recently, two ex-circus lions but they don't want to stop there! The Trust is now keen to look into the rescue of bile bears from Asia, and Barbery macaques from North Africa. Animals that never have, nor ever will be able to live in the wild.

They cannot do this alone and need help and assistance from like-minded individuals to assist in their rescue and rehabilitation work!
Title: Fundraising Friday - Commercial Microwave for The Animal Kitchen

Description:
Every year since 2004, the North Wales link of the Chernobyl Children’s Lifeline Charity has been bringing children from Belarus & the Ukraine over to North Wales for a one month health respite visit. These children & their families are still suffering the devastating effects of the Chernobyl disaster, over 30 years later.  The conditions these families live in is heartbreaking.  Most families do not have the basic facilities that we take for granted such as running water in our homes & indoor toilets. 

The children are born with such low immune systems they often suffer from ill health, with many developing cancer.  Just four weeks staying with host families can help to prolong their lives by up to 4 years!

For those 4 weeks the children stay with host families, with the charity organising fun days out and activities during the week where they get to just enjoy being children & meeting the people who so generously donate clothes, gifts & supplies. They are taken to the dentist, the opticians & are supplied with immune boosting vitamins during their visit.  We also collect medical supplies such as paracetamol, sudocrem, plasters, antiseptic creams etc to take home to the families.

Bringing these children over every year is only part of what the link is all about. We are constantly fundraising so we can support the families back home in Belarus & the Ukraine. We have just successfully raised enough money to provide a toilet block for the village school, next on the agenda is providing them with a school kitchen & dining area as what they currently use is indescribable. 

Thank you for taking the time to read this & if you are able to donate thank you so much!! Keep an eye out for updates & if you’d like to get in touch or see what the children have been up to follow our facebook page. 

https://en-gb.facebook.com/NorthWalesCCLL/

Description:
I will be DJing for 24-hours non-stop from 8pm on Friday 5th Feb right through until 8pm on the Saturday evening!

The amazing team at Helping our Homeless Wales need our support - the van which they use to deliver vital food and supplies all across Wales and into Herefordshire is knackered and has to be replaced - I want to help them raise the £3,500 they need.

With lockdown 3.0 in full effect, staying in is back as the new going out, so I’ll be doing my best to put some much-needed sparks on your (indoor, socially distant) sparklers!

I will be streaming live from The Globe in Hay via my Mixcloud page from dusk until dawn and then back to dusk again, with a very special and very, very extended set. As well as the usual dance-floor bangers, disco debauchery and high-energy party house, I will be taking you on a cosmic journey via the best in soul, reggae, D&B, 90’s trance and even some ’80’s re-edits! 

In return please can you donate what you can to the appeal through this page and help us smash the target.

As part of my set from 2pm - 4pm on the Saturday afternoon I will be switching across to host my new radio show on the EXT Radio Mixcloud page for a couple of hours which I’m super excited about - let’s hope I’m still awake!

So dig out your glad rags, dust off your dancing shoes, grab your cocktail shaker, plug in your disco lights, tell your mates and get involved!

Description:
Remember how a couple of years ago I helped raise funds for a township classroom for some of the most poverty stricken children in South Africa? Well I'm visiting Cape Town in April 2019 and I have learned that some children still don't have kitchen where nutritious food can be prepared safely.

I have some amazing friends who have supported me already. Arafat Gatabazi swam with me at the Cape of Good Hope Castle. Sarah Gray held a 'sing for your super' event and lots of you came to the fundraising evening at Longhoughton, Westfield Park

Thanks to your generosity these children now have a classroom 


I would love to be able to contribute to a kitchen facility when I visit in April. I will do something crazy when I'm there to thank you for your donations - climb a mountain in the searing heat or find somewhere unusual to swim (hopefully croc, shark & hippo free). 

I'm travelling to Swedish Lapland this weekend to swim in the coldest river in Sweden. The air will be minus 15'c and the water below zero too (I'm doing this whilst recovering from a chest infection)

Please will you donate? I have 900 friends on facebook. If everyone donates a couple of quid it will go a long way to supporting these beautiful children who deserve the basics

Many many thanks

Title: David's Movember for Maggie's

Description:
I’m walking the Ingleborough with my friends to raise awareness for eating disorders and get GP’s better training in the field of diagnosing and treating Ed sufferers!

 One of the saving graces for my mental health is getting out in nature with my friends. One of our favourite things to do is what we call our ‘soup and a sunset’ dates where we make a new soup recipe and go on a walk onto watch the sunset. This challenge means a lot to me because my eating disorder took memories like these with friends away from me for a long time. I didn’t allow myself to eat with friends and saw exercise solely as a gruelling workout that wasn’t meant to be enjoyed. Recovery has allowed me to cherish these moments with friends, enjoy moving my body and not feeling guilty about eating bread … I curse my eating disorder for letting me believe that bread is the devil. A warm crusty roll dipped in homemade soup, in a field watching the sunset with friends will solve EVERYTHING. I meant it. 

I've struggled with an eating disorder for over ten years, and still, one of the scariest parts of the illness is speaking about it. But, there is no recovery without talking. I carried a lot of shame for putting my loved ones through the stress that my anorexia caused, because of this I felt guilty speaking to them when I began to struggle again. I felt like I'd let them down. But, the first conversation, just like the first mouthful, is always the hardest, (albeit never as bad as I think it will be.) Active recovery is an everyday battle, one that I have to gently nudge myself on every day. If there's one thing that makes it easier, that's not being ashamed to ask for help. I've lost years, memories and friends to this illness. Your funds can help to make the treatment for eating disorders more accessible and treatable for those suffering.

I've been turned away from, treated badly and belittled by many GP's. I was refused help until I was hours away from death - if my eating disorder was treated earlier then my recovery could've been quicker and I could've stayed at home for treatment. Early treatment saves lives but in a survey of 1,700 people of those who'd asked for help, 72% had waited for more than six months to do so.

I want to live in a world where I could go to a GP and be taken as seriously as someone with a broken leg instead of being told to 'eat more.' It needs to change and we can do this by raising money to train GP's adequately.  The average GP only gets  2hours of training dedicated to eating disorders throughout their entire medical degree and a fifth of UK medical schools don't give training at all. 67% of respondents felt that some of the early warning signs were missed. If GP's know what to look for, they can ask important questions and refer people for treatment much sooner.

Description:
We were meant to hold our cake bake this week, but we’re not letting working-from-home get in the way of us raising money for a good cause. So step away from your lap-top and get out your food mixer.

When?

Entries must be in by 12 noon on Friday 29 January.

How will it work?

There will be two categories – one for children (under 12)
and one for adults.

Just whip up your best baking and send a picture and description into the Aegon AM UK Charity MB. Our cake-loving judges will then decide who is our best baker – there is a promise of a (modest) prize – but more importantly, you could have the glory of being the winner of the 2021 Virtual Bake-Off.

Our judges will be Anne Scott and Alistair Fruzynski of Nuffield gym.  Many of you have participated in Alistair’s popular exercise classes, which you can link to from the intranet.  More classes have been included for example, Yoga, Body Tone and exercises you can do at your desk.   Classes are free to all staff. So if you feel you have eaten too much cake, there is plenty of opportunity to burn it off!

Please sponsor your colleagues and donate generously to Cure Parkinson's Trust, our 2021 charity of the year.

About Cure Parkinson's Trust

Founded in 2005 by four people living with the condition, the Cure Parkinson's Trust (CPT) takes a patient-centric approach to funding innovative projects and inspirational scientists, working to modify the progression of Parkinson’s and to find a cure. At CPT we believe that we are closer than ever to delivering treatments that for the first time will slow, stop or even reverse the progression of the disease. Your donation will help us get there.

CharityId: England and Wales (802047) and in Scotland (SC0407
Description:
Having a child in hospital is a frightening time for families, more so amongst a global pandemic. Three Cranswick sites (Gourmet Kitchen, Gourmet Sausage and Convenience) are teaming up with the aim of raising money for Ronald McDonald House Charity to support the families who have children in hospital. Starting from Wednesday 17th for 72hours, Cranswick Gourmet Sausage and Cranswick Convenience Foods are going head to head in a cycling Peloton Challenge to see how many miles they do between them, whilst also deciding which site will go champion. 

Ronald McDonald House Charities UK provides free ‘home away from home’ accommodation to families with children having treatment in hospital. Our Houses offer much more than just a place to stay; they provide family activities, peer support, respite, and many other services. This means that families can be by their child’s bedside in a matter of moments, whilst maintaining a degree of normal life with reduced emotional and financial strain.We help over 6,000 families each year and now, more than ever, we need your support. Thank you.
Title: Cranswick Gourmet Kitchen Head to Head Peloton Challenge

Description:
Thom volunteered with Refugee Comminity Kitchen in Calais some years ago and it was a charity he continued to support. Thom was passionate about charity and I'm sure he would appreciate any small donation to the cause. 

Below is a bit about the charity and what your money will go towards. 

Refugee Community Kitchen serves hot, nourishing meals to displaced people in the UK and France.

We support displaced people in Northern France and homeless people in London and Edinburgh. We give people more than a hot meal, we give them a place to gather and connect. Somewhere to recreate a community - providing spaces for medical and legal services, safeguarding groups and other support organisation and people in need to meet.

We’ve been serving food in Calais and Northern France since 2015. Since the Calais Jungle was demolished we have been forced to constantly adapt our distribution points and styles. We currently serve food wherever we can find a safe place for people to congregate in the Calais and Dunkirk regions.

After maintaining a number of their UK Outreach services throughout the pandemic, they are ready to rebuild in Northern France and to resume full service throughout the UK. A small COVID-19 response team, including the co-founders, are re-opening the kitchen, assessing the need in the region and slowly, safely and ethically rebuilding our operations accordingly. 

They we need your support as they rebuild! Please donate and share, so that they can rebuild their stores of essentials such as rice, spices, gloves, beans, oil, fresh veg, fuel and much more!

£10 = 12 litres of cooking oil

£20 = 75 tins of tomatoes

£50 = 55kg Basmati rice

£100 = 85kg dried beans

RCK is 100% dependent on donations, they really need your support in this crucial time. Please help them get back on their feet so that they can continue our mission of serving nutritious food without judgement.
Title: Thom Rewcastle's Memorial Fundraiser for Refugee Community Kitchen

Description:
Thank you for visiting our JustGiving page.

We are raising funds for Kitchen Social, part of the Mayor’s Fund for London, to provide healthy recipe boxes to children during the school
holidays. We want to make a positive difference for children in our local area and we would love your help.  

The pandemic has had a devastating impact on children’s access to food. In London alone, 400,000 children currently face food insecurity, and right here in our local area of Southwark, increasing numbers of children are eligible for free school meals, leaving them vulnerable to holiday hunger outside of term time, during weekends and holidays. Over the course of this pandemic, Southwark Council estimates the number of children eligible for free school meals has doubled.

These children are in desperate need of our support over the holiday period. 

Last year, Kitchen Social was able to distribute 15,989 Take & Make boxes across our local area, equating to 63,956 meals. Take and Make Boxes are designed to get children to cook healthy food in their homes – every box contains high quality, healthy ingredients with step-by-step instructions and video tutorials, providing an educational, familial and dignified solution to holiday hunger.
 

With so much in the news this year about school meals and food insecurity, we reached out to charities working in our local area, and we identified that Kitchen Social was making a tremendous difference right here in Southwark.  

We would be delighted to have your support – gifts of any size can provide food for a family that needs our help during the school holidays.  

All donations will go directly to The Mayor’s Fund for London charity and will be used to provide ‘Take and Make’ weekend meal boxes for children in Southwark who desperately need them.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On the 5th July 2018 my youngest son Milo was born, he was immediately taken to ICU as he was clearly very poorly. Over the next day he began to show symptoms of a problem which, having been transferred to Brighton was diagnosed as a twisted bowel. My wife was unable to travel and I followed Milo down to Brighton were he was operated on in the early hours.

After 3hrs of surgery, Milo surgeon delivered us the good news that the bowel had been reattached and that no lasting damage had been done. Eventually my wife was able to travel down to Brighton to be reunited with Milo & I could return home to look after our eldest Felix with the hope that all would be fine & within a week or so we would be home.

Unfortunately Milo although growing stronger & getting over the infection he was born with he was unable to eat & so further investigations were needed. After a few weeks & many journeys down to Brighton he was eventually diagnosed with Hirschsprung Disease.

https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hirschsprungs-disease/

Having had a pull through operation at 3 months to remove 10cm of his colon. Milo is now 13 months and doing brilliantly. But challengers lie ahead and a little donation to CHAMPS appeal will raise much need awareness by bringing families with HD children together & supporting families in understanding the diseases and improving awareness of it.

Thanks Freddie, Lizzie, Felix & Milo
Title: Milo's Wild Seasoning Kitchen Asian Inspired Supperclubs

Title: BABM Freshers Freshen

Description:
Why

I have personally benefitted from MIND
(Abingdon) services, the last couple of years have been extremely
turbulent for me, we ‘as a family’ have been victim to three family
bereavements in the last 14 Months! Clearly, this had a massive negative impact
on my outlook on life, MIND offered me talking therapy which help
me understand my feelings and positively greave whilst keeping my family’s
wellbeing intact, for me I learnt that “its ok, not to be ok”! they provided me
coping mechanisms to alleviate the overwhelming feelings of helplessness and
isolation.

As a serving soldier I understand just
how hard it can be to admit that you need help, the tough exterior that we
portray can act as a barrier between being comfortable in our own skin.
however, acknowledgment that help is required is the first step to wellbeing.

MIND charity

At least one in four of us will
experience mental health issues in any one year. MIND (Abingdon) charity
is an organisation that supports patients overcome complexed mental health
trauma. MIND promote mental wellbeing strategies through the
provision of professional Councillors who promote positive change and
signposting to an array of excellent services. which include housing, talking
therapies, benefits advice, a confidential and free information, not forgetting
on-line courses.

MIND Abingdon centre has worked intimately with 3 and 4 Regt RLC
over the last few years offering soldiers of all ranks professional sympathetic
support, it cannot be overstated just what a positive impact MIND has had on
our serving soldiers. Solely relying on donations to operate. MIND depend
on the goodwill of others to function. This prompted my enthusiasm to raise
funds.

Aim

We aim to raise £4000 between the two
Regt's this will go towards replacing their kitchen. thus, allowing them to do more
coffee, lunch, tea and cake afternoons, as well as cook for special occasions
i.e., offering the vulnerable some rest bite in a safe and a welcoming
environment.

I’m sure you will agree we are raising
money for this great cause. We will be walking 70 miles in 24 hours with 35kg
on our backs simulating the depression burden that those suffering inhabit.

If you wish to donate any amount for
this fantastic charity, please scan the QR Code or following the link provided.

“Please help them to help others”
Title: 3 & 4 Regt RLC walking 70 miles for MINDS Abingdon

Title: Paul Cannon's Birthday

Description:
Seeing first hand the amazing work the team at the Larder do has inspired me to take on a challenge to raise awareness and funds to support the Larders amazing work supporting those experiencing food insecurity in West Lothian! 

So the paddle against food poverty was born! This will involve myself stand up paddleboarding 10 lochs end to end totaling 150km in 6 days! from the 6th to 11th June 2022 finishing on the shores of Loch Rannoch! The goal is to raise 5K to allow the Larder to support more people in need via the Catalyst Kitchen and to raise awareness of the issue of food poverty in our communities! 

With prices rising and the squeeze on peoples budgets this will push more household into various forms of Poverty. According to the scottish government in 2017 19% of the population were experiencing some form of poverty that's 1 million people! and this was pre-pandemic. As a first world country this is unacceptable and more needs to be done to find a long term and dignified solution to support those experiencing poverty.

During the pandemic The Larder created the Catalyst Kitchen project in a direct response to the increase to those experiencing food insecurity in West Lothian 

The Catalyst Kitchen was designed to disrupt the national answer to food insecurity, an answer which provides no choice, no control and no dignity. This project supports our community through pop-up dining experiences, community 'Cook and Dine' classes and the delivery of quality cooked and chilled meals delivered to doors and community pantries. Catalyst Kitchen has and continues to be described as “a lifeline”, “revolutionary”, “invaluable”, “life-changing”.

When the pandemic hit in March 2020 and face-to-face dining experiences were no longer able to be held, Catalyst Kitchen quickly pivoted services to the delivery of freshly cooked, chilled meals; launched 3rd of April 2020.

Food made by The Larder chefs, and where possible, supported by young people in training is distributed by a team of volunteers on a weekly basis either directly to beneficiaries’ doors or to local pick-up points based in partnership organisations.

Since launch, The Larder have delivered over 120,000 meals to over 800 beneficiaries. 

Not only does The Larder provide a meal service to those in need but also works to break down isolation with the weekly dining experience serviced by The Larders trainees. The team at the Larder look to address the causes and barriers of beneficiaries may be experiencing through The Larders - Cook and dine classes.

These classes are free to those who are experiencing food insecurity; meaning limited access to food as a result of personal, financial or health issues.

The Larder’s talented chefs will coach beneficiaries through preparation, cooking skills, food planning and budgeting whilst making delicious meals from scratch. After the class, Beneficiaries will join their fellow classmates for a sit-down meal cooked with their own hands!

The Larder chefs will guide beneficiaries through this three-hour class, leaving them with new confidence and skills to take home; along with the recipes they have been cooking!

The Catalyst Kitchen provides a vital service to the West lothian Community and to help support the and raise and my supporting me you can help to have a impact to those most in need in our community and help to fight and alleviate food poverty.

Description:
2021 was a tough year for everyone! I see from friends, family & local business owners, the challenges that everyone face and are still facing - from being apart from loved ones and altering our daily way of life (wearing masks to complex and sometimes confusing measures) to protect the ones we love...but I can't imagine how difficult it would be for someone who has Alzheimer's disease. 

Within my own family, we saw how Alzheimer's affected my Grandpa, Les. Seeing the heartbreaking decline of him in his later years but just like the COVID-19 pandemic, I saw my family adjusting their lives to care for him. Having support from charities like Alzheimer's Society made a huge difference to his life and those caring for him.

I'm looking to raise money and awareness of this wonderful charity that does brilliant work by getting care to those who need it and offering support to carers. I will be trekking up the Three Peaks in Yorkshire; Pen-y-Ghent, Whernside and Ingleborough over a total of 7000ft climbed in under 12 hours!

I hope you can put something to this amazing cause and let's find a cure!

#sharetheorange

Get Support

Description:
After maintaining a number of their UK Outreach services throughout the pandemic, they are ready to rebuild in Northern France and to resume full service throughout the UK. A small COVID-19 response team, including the co-founders, are re-opening the kitchen, assessing the need in the region and slowly, safely and ethically rebuilding our operations accordingly. 

They we need your support as we rebuild!

Please donate and share, so that they can rebuild our stores of essentials such as rice, spices, gloves, Vegware, beans, oil, fresh veg, fuel and much more!

£10 = 12 litres of cooking oil

£20 = 75 tins of tomatoes

£50 = 55kg Basmati rice

£100 = 85kg dried beans

RCK is 100% dependent on donations, they really need your support in this crucial time. Please help us get back on their feet so that we can continue our mission of serving nutritious food without judgement.

Description:
See our video here:
https://vimeo.com/691582800/1ffd512d2d

In response to the humanitarian crisis in Ukraine, Natural Products Expo West and their parent company, Informa, have donated $100,000 to World Central Kitchen

This non-profit of food first responders provide nourishing meals to those effected by natural disasters, man-made crises, and humanitarian emergencies around the world. 

Within 24-hours of the Russian invasion, World Central Kitchen began serving refugees at eight border crossings and assisting local restaurants in several Ukrainian cities.

Please join us as we support the Ukranian people by providing vital nutrition through this important non-profit.

Let’s band together to help those affected now!
Title: Expo West and New Hope Fundraiser for World Central Kitchen

Description:
Since 2015 something extraordinary has happened when thousands of fellow human beings have come close to home needing help, we have got up and helped and whilst doing that we have unintentionally created a new way of helping that’s accessible to all.A revolutionary way of helping that provides humanity and nourishment to hungry and vulnerable people creating a connected and kinder world & our mission is to give highly nutritional food support to displaced people whatever their situation. Food is a language the crosses all borders.

In the words of our founder Max.....


"This group was never about trade in the economic sense. It was always about humanity and it was always about love. And it was also about understanding that music is an *essential* element of our being human. We have every reason to think that communities have been singing, playing, drumming and dancing together for hundreds of thousands of years, with every song and beat binding people together, literally creating and perpetuating harmony across our planet.

In our modern world, and contrary to all our instincts, we have commodified our artistic output and although we have created great art, high and low, in the process, we have also forgotten that music belongs to us all. If you have ever felt like expressing yourself artistically but stopped because you felt that your art was not worthy, the Viral Jukebox is your home. I mean it.

More than once since I created this group people have suggested that I could find a way to monetise it. They are missing the point. The currency here is love. Spend freely. Give freely. And remember, if you sang or played it from your heart, you played it right."

So this Christmas, with the Pandemic rolling on and weird hybrid lockdown in place, we thought it would be great to raise money, together, for our favourite causes, so choose the one closest to your heart (or follow the person who made a song you like and vote for a cause they love!)

Happy Christmas Jukeboxers!
Title: Viral Jukebox Christmas Crackers - Christmas Songs for Refugee Kitchen

I work for Linden Lodge Neuro-rehabilitation Unit at Nottingham City Hospital. We care for and provide rehabilitation to patients that have complex brain and spinal injuries as well as those with long term disabilities such as multiple sclerosis (MS). We are trying to raise funds to upgrade the patient kitchen area. 

This is used for therapeutic sessions as well as encouraging independence for those patients that are able to make their own food and drinks.

The plan is to have new units, cooker and equipment. Even better would be able to have enough to have a "floating" work surface that will allow all patients, whether wheelchair bound or standing, to be able to utilise the space. We know that it is going to be expensive - in the region of around £15,000 and that this will only be a small step towards it.

I am hoping to raise at least £500 for a complete head shave - please be generous!
Title: Helen's brave the Shave for Linden Lodge

Title: liam's Cake sale

Description:
This week we received news of a devastating storm at the Special School at Mvomero!  Luckily everyone is safe, but the damage is extensive.

The Special School for the Deaf at Mvomero has been working really hard to establish itself as a government primary school. The staff go the extra mile to support these children with hearing impairment helping them succeed at primary level. The work they do is important...

This unusually violent storm hit the School, destroying the kitchen, the water tanks, the cowsheds, chicken-house, and much more... 

The priority now is to secure a water supply, get the kitchen up and running again (this provides meals for 40 children and staff), as well as providing protection for the animals (these provide food for the community as well as an income). The heavy rains are due at the beginning of February so we need to make significant progress in making repairs very quickly.
Title: Amani Special School's Emergency Appeal

The Peoples Kitchen Charity was established in 1985.
Registered charity number 1036149.

They provide friendship and food, 52 weeks a year, 40 hot meals 6 days a week, clothing, sleeping bags, shower facilities and programmes to help towards independent living, combat loneliness and isolation.

They have 200+ volunteers who donate their time free and they have no government grants.

Along with opening their doors they also have a catering van they use 3 half days a week providing food around Newcastle. At the moment they are trying to raise £50,000 to replace their catering van to continue their work in the community and help their friends who are not able to attend the Kitchen.

One day a week the Kitchen opens their doors to invite their friends to karaoke nights, ramblers clubs and more...

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In February 2020 I had a life enriching  trip to Memusi school in Magadi, Kenya along with other volunteers.The foundation has established three schools over the last 15 yrs supporting over 1000 primary children aged 3-14 from the local Masai community. Many of these children walk for miles to school each day from their villages and the school provides often their only hot meal of the day. The current kitchen was built for 100 children but now they feed 400.

Many of these children live in homes with no electricity or running water including my sponsored son Brian. The teachers I met were inspirational and welcomed all the volunteers with open arms and certainly touched my heart.

When Peter and I both retire next year ,we will return to Memusi as soon as we are allowed and will help with education and healthcare.

It would be wonderful if there could be a new kitchen in place to feed all the children and buy food and goats for the community. Starvation has been a major concern for the foundation over the pandemic.
Title: Gill's Appeal to raise money for a new kitchen and to support Memusi school

Title: Don't be shocked, I should turn 40 on 15th April but I'm staying 39!

Description:
Happy birthday to me!

For the past few years, I have undertaken a running challenge on my birthday (24th February), raising funds for the Andrew Grene Foundation. I am the director of fundraising, so it seems fitting
for me to step up once a year and “put my money where my mouth is”, so to speak!

My challenges have ranged from a half-marathon in Haiti in the heat, to running everyday in February. We have all had a tough couple of years, but throughout these times, our supporters have stayed engaged with us, even though we have been unable to visit them or our projects in person, due to all the various restrictions. 

So, this year, to say thank you to all our dedicated supporters, and to really challenge myself, I have decided to run a marathon.  But not in the traditional sense!  This marathon will be run, one mile, every
hour, for 26 hours.  I will start at 6am on my birthday (24th Feb) and finish at 8am on the following day.  The last mile will be 1.2 miles to make up the full marathon distance.

We need new cooking facilities at the Andrew Grene High
School.  Currently, we use charcoal to heat the food for the lunches we provide for all students and staff daily, but this is expensive bad for the environment, so we would like to replace our current cooking facilities with new gas stoves. The cost of implementing these changes is £2,500 so that is my fundraising target for this challenge.

You are invited to join me for one or as many miles as you like during the 26-hour running period, so no matter where you are in the world, your time difference won’t matter – so no excuses!  You can sign up for your mile via our website www.andrewgrene.org

I will be available via video link on WhatsApp during the challenge, and will run on the hour every hour, so if you are joining me, please do let me know and we can link up and enjoy the mile together (virtually).

I look forward to seeing as many of you as possible for one
(or more) miles over the 26-hour period, and thank you as always, for your ongoing support.

Jane
Title: Jane's 26 Hour Running Challenge

On Saturday 25th June I will be running the Round Sheffield Run, a 24km multi-stage trail running expo. I am doing this to raise funds for and in support of The People's Kitchen who are the Central & North Places for People Development Teams chosen charity for 2022.

The People's Kitchen is a safe haven for many people who's lives can be chaotic. They support the homeless by serving over 140 meals every day, 364 days a year.

To make sure everyone receives the friendship needed to navigate tough times, they also have a team making support calls. By chatting over the phone, they help combat loneliness and boost wellbeing for people who feel isolated or struggle with their mental health.

If you feel that you are able to support me in any way then your support is appreciated...even if it's just shouting from the sidelines.

Description:
We are a team of 40+ PGT/PGR students and staff members in MHSES. We take up the challenge of walking or running 5K per day between 14th May and 10th June and fundraise for the Refugee Community Kitchen (RCK)!

 
RCK is a charity that supports displaced people in Northern France and homeless people in London and Edinburgh. Since 2015, RCK has served nutritious food without judgement to those fleeing war, poverty, persecution and climate change and living in Northern France and the UK.

 
“RCK is based in Calais and has two smaller bases in London. I was there recently, and they were struggling a bit but still providing a hot meal for 1000+ asylum seekers daily. Around 7 or 8 countries of origin, some African, some middle Eastern.” – A volunteer

 
Please support us in taking the challenge, and donate to RCK!

Description:

Title: Jolly Jumper Week

Description:
Everyone deserves to feel a sense of belonging; I believe this notion can be found everywhere and anywhere, yet when environments are openly hostile to ones presence, its hard to cultivate this sense of place. This is why the Refugee Community Kitchen is such a valuable initiative, for they are nourishing, nurturing and so unifying displaced people in Northern France, through cooking and distributing hot, culturally sensitive meals in a safe space. 

Active since 2015, the RCK have continued to operate despite the turbulence of camp destruction, police brutality and settlement evictions. The unpredictable Covid-19 restrictions and looming winter months are placing further strains on their mission and to add to the crisis, in early October the French authorities imposed limitations on food distribution within Calais. Clearly, the RCK needs the love and support right now so they may continue providing safe, judgement free spaces where people can gather and tap into a sense of belonging, so vital in these disturbing circumstances. 

In December I will be venturing to Calais to help the RCK continue their phenomenal work. I believe an opportunity to aid hundreds of people, right on our doorstep, who are going without the essentials to human well-being is a privilege not to be passed up. Equally, the profound effect a nourishing meal can have on the body, mind and spirit is truly miraculous, therefore I invite you to open your heart and support my mission, in doing so, the RCK and all the people they serve. 

Contributing could look like diverting your coffee money (or perhaps your lunch money!) towards this fundraiser; sharing this page to family, friends, (or foes...). Equally, if you’d like to donate kitchen supplies and materials instead of funds, please follow the link bellow to see their ‘Food/Kitchen Needs List’ and reach out. I will organise the collection, storage and transportation of these life-changing supplies ready for December. 

Any act of kindness would be gratefully received; it means the world that you are on this page right now, ready to make a difference.

Love and Light

Ari <3 


Food/Kitchen Needs List: 

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Byxq9mQj3bPvq5WRxRZHfApBqTGGMVmjxq34Maspqa4/edit
Title: Ari's Calais Mission

Description:
I made the decision a while back to grow out my hair and donate 12 inches! On the 22nd of December it will be cut off and I would love to be able to donate as much money as possible to some amazing charities. Below is the before photo and the after photo will be coming soon! 

The charities are the little princess trust who will take my hair and 50% of the donations so they can make it into a wig for someone who has lost their hair due to illness. The other charity is the refugee community kitchen which is close to my heart as I was able to volunteer and see the amazing work they do for displaced people in Calais. 

The refugee community kitchen make fresh healthy  meals for displaced people in Calais. Over the years they have managed to help 2,913,750 people. However they are struggling to keep up with demand in the current climate and any donations would make a huge impact.

Title: Gemma Lynch & Claire MacRae's Wedding

Description:
Their mission is to support homeless and disadvantaged people in the Newcastle area, as we have been doing since 1985. 

Their vision is to play a unique role in the City’s efforts to meet the needs of homeless and vulnerable people



Food is the vital first step in helping our Friends towards a better future. Without The People’s Kitchen many of our Friends would struggle to afford every day essentials, like a hot meal. We provide 40,000 hot meals a year, from our own premises at the Alison Centre in central Newcastle, and from our mobile kitchen which takes to the streets three times a week. Hot food, clean clothes and warm bedding are a lifeline to our most vulnerable visitors, many of whom suffer from mental illness, physical disability, drug and alcohol misuse, or are rough sleepers.

Description:
The Killingworth Community Choir have been rehearsing and performing locally for nearly 5 years. When lockdown hit, we decided to meet virtually (thanks to the kind sharing of the St. John's Church zoom account), but for a while we only did quizzes due to the delay issues with zoom. 

Since September we have been singing along on mute while our tireless musical director Selwyn plays the keyboard for us all to sing along. 

We decided to make a recording of Christmas songs as we have missed performing so much. Angela had the clever idea of sharing the recordings on social media along with a Justgiving page to raise the funds that our end of year concert usually generates for charity.

Christine's granddaughter Katy wrote to the committee all the way back in January (before we had heard of lockdown/furlough/COVID etc) to ask that if we raise money this year, please can it be to help people who have become homeless. So this is our way to do this in a socially distanced way.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

At the end of November, 'The Friends of Sherborne Preparatory School' set off on a virtual challenge of 32,400 miles to visit 'Friends Around the Globe'.  Visiting Doha, Singapore, Auckland and Tianjin, China we were able to hold virtual assemblies with our friends and learn about our amazing planet on the way. By logging our walks, runs, cycles, swims, rows and even skiing our amazing Team has propelled our schools Red Dragon across Europe, the Middle East, Asia, the heat of the Australian outback and the bitter
Siberian Winter. In the coming week our intrepid Red Dragon will be coming home after a phenomenal journey without a plane, train or automobile in sight!

Please help us raise £324, 1p/mile, for the amazing Sherborne Community Kitchen who have done such an incredible job looking after our local community in these difficult times.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page! There are a few reasons why I have chosen to do Dry January in aid of The People's Kitchen. Born in Newcastle thirty years ago, the charity aims to combat a growing homelessness and isolation problem that I've seen consistently in my time living there. Through outreach programs that provide food and warmth for the city's displaced, the People's Kitchen is a worthy charity for anyone that has ever imagined what spending a night in the freezing cold would be like. 

I'm personally done with hangovers and my widening overdraft for the moment, (let's see if the two correlate), and I hope that giving up the devil's juice for a month is a good pathway to express my frustration with homelessness we are confronted with all around us, on a daily basis.

I am absolutely petrified of heights (I don't even wear heels for flips sake!), so this is a massive personal challenge for me, so as well as raising money for the charity, I will be pushing myself to conquer my own fears. 

So please give if you can, I'll accept anything but buttons!!
Take care of you and thanks again for stopping by.

Love Pam,
With kisses on the bottom xx

Title: Steve bedlam's Birthday

Description:
Make a meal 🍲 Make a donation 💰 Nominate three friends 👨‍👧‍👦

This winter, let's stay in and cook up a storm in support of refugees.

To take part all you need to do is make a meal at home (preferably delicious and nutritious!) and to donate some of what you might have otherwise spent out, to the Refugee Community Kitchen.

Once having done that, share a photo of your gorgeous grub on Instagram, tagging @EatInToHelpOut and nominating three friends to do the same. 

We understand these are tough times for all, so whatever you can donate is amazing, no matter how much.


Why we're doing this

We're doing this in support of the brilliant Refugee Community Kitchen who are working hard to provide healthy meals to as many displaced people as they can in the UK and France.

Speaking to their founder, we found out that they need £6,300 every week to serve 10,000 meals, so we've set our target to exactly that and hope that we can stretch it to a whole month if we surpass £6,300 (a whole month would be 44,000 meals!)

If you give just £6, you'll be providing over 9 whole meals!

We all know that food brings people together, and we believe now it can do so more than ever. So get cooking, with family and friends, and let's really show that in the UK we choose love and stand with refugees.

Thank you so so much for your support, and please do SHARE THIS PAGE! You really are making a difference to people's lives.


Refugee Community Kitchen – Serving food with dignity

Refugee Community Kitchen serves hot, nourishing meals to displaced people in the UK and France. Since 2015 they have provided over 2.9 million meals with a team of over 18,000 volunteers.

“We give people more than a hot meal, we give them a place to gather and connect. Somewhere to recreate a community - providing space for medical and legal services, safeguarding groups and other support.”

With Covid-19 having affected everything they do, they need everyone's help more than ever! That's what caused us to come up with this idea, and that's why we need you 🙌

Please do take part in Eat In To Help Out, and SHARE THIS PAGE! Your one action can make a genuinely big difference to displaced people's lives. Let's choose love, show that refugees are welcome in the UK, and have some delicious dinners whilst at it. Thank you 🥰

Description: Our Big Kitchen is a community kitchen in the heart of Bondi that inspires individuals to come together to help people in need. Title: Nick's The retirement of Phil Ansell

Description:
Hey!

My dissertation deadline is just weeks away, and entering probably the busiest time of my life...sounds like the perfect time to do something crazy in the name of charity!

This Saturday I will be taking part in the NUCATS 24-hour charity gameathon. I'll be honest, I'm gonna miss a few hours of it because I already bought tickets to watch Newcastle get thumped by Southampton (just what I need to get my spirits up going into a gaming all-nighter). And I'm playing the drums in church on Sunday morning...hmm...

A few lucky people get paid millions to play video games full-time. I just ask that you give what you can to a fantastic cause, the People's Kitchen Newcastle. As a team we are aiming to raise £3000 for the charity.

It's upsetting walking round Newcastle and seeing the lives that homeless people often choose to live because they have no better option. The People's Kitchen offers warmth and cheer for so many on the streets, and gives us hope that one day the situation will be gone for good.

The plan is to spend the best part of the day (and night) getting my Ultimate Team [Mbemba the Name] from shoddy division 6 up to division 1. If you're really bored enough to want to watch me shout at the Xbox and commentate, I'm thinking to do a Twitch stream too.

It would mean so much to me that you give what you can. Video games are fun but doing it for a cause like this (when I probably should be in the library instead) is so worth it.

Matthew x

On Saturday the 7th January we are going to host a coffee morning at our house to raise money for the People's Kitchen in Newcastle.

From their site: ' We have been supporting those who need our help in Newcastle for three decades.

Established thanks to one woman’s determination, our organisation has grown enormously from its humble beginnings under the railway arches at Dean Street, but our philosophy remains the same. We continue to offer clothes, food, warm surroundings, and a warm welcome to anyone that needs our help.'

A brilliant charity who work so hard to provide support to many vulnerable people. Providing food for those in need, providing friendship and also helping them to build happier futures. Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page, I really
appreciate you taking the time to do so.

As you may all know I'm leaving the University at Christmas to take up a new role in a Primary School in the East of Newcastle. I'm really excited to be taking on this new challenge however I'm equally sad to be saying goodbye to so many great friends and colleagues and an organisation that’s been a huge part of my life for the last 27 years. It’s safe to say I will miss you all.


Because I realise I'm one of the lucky people in this world I thought rather than a collection for me, I'd like my leaving gift to be a donation
to the People's Kitchen – I’m sure this will be particularly welcome at this time of year. Founded as a soup kitchen in 1985, The Peoples Kitchen has evolved to offer a range of services to those in
need, they provide up to 100 hot meals a night as well as clothing and
toiletries for those who are less fortunate.

Best wishes

Tracey

For the first event, we’re off to Mexico! And this one is going to be a fundraiser for Refugee Community Kitchen, with all profits going to them. RCK are an amazing charity, that provide hot, nutritious & delicious food to people who really need it here in London & Calais. For this one, donations will be made through our Just giving page (click here). We suggest £30 p/h but we’d like it to be open to everyone so please donate what you can. After donating, please pop us an email with your name, any dietaries and the other people in your gang, so we can sit you together. Please don’t put your name as anonymous! 

We look forward to having you around our table, with a margarita (or two) and the sound of mariachis in the background! Check out the other evenings via billetto (link in bio), incase you fancy coming along. :) 

With much excitement and love, 

Aitana & Sarah 


Since 2015 something extraordinary has happened when thousands of fellow human beings have come close to home needing help, we have got up and helped and whilst doing that we have unintentionally created a new way of helping that’s accessible to all.A revolutionary way of helping that provides humanity and nourishment to hungry and vulnerable people creating a connected and kinder world & our mission is to give highly nutritional food support to displaced people whatever their situation.Food is a language the crosses all borders
Title: Aitana & Sarah 's The Little Cooking Pot Mexican Supperclub // RCK fundraiser // Lizzy's on the green

Description:
£10 = 12 litres of cooking oil

£20 = 75 tins of tomatoes

£50 = 55kg Basmati rice

£100 = 85kg dried beans

Rum Shack Live At Union Chapel is donating 20% of ticket sales to our friends at Refugee Community Kitchen

Rum Shack was founded by Steve Bedlam, who went on to co-found Refugee Community Kitchen. RCK are close to our hearts at The Common Glastonbury (our field) and we have witnessed their remarkable and tireless work first hand. Please help us support them.

After maintaining a number of their UK Outreach services throughout the pandemic, they are ready to rebuild in Northern France and to resume full service throughout the UK. A small COVID-19 response team, including the co-founders, are re-opening the kitchen, assessing the need in the region and slowly, safely and ethically rebuilding our operations accordingly. 

They need your support as they rebuild!

Please donate and share, so that they can rebuild our stores of essentials such as rice, spices, gloves, Vegware, beans, oil, fresh veg, fuel and much more!

RCK is 100% dependent on donations, they really need your support in this crucial time. Please help us get back on their feet so that we can continue our mission of serving nutritious food without judgement.

https://refugeecommunitykitchen.org/

https://www.instagram.com/rumshackglasto

https://www.instagram.com/lyrixorganix/
Title: Rum Shack: Help Refugee Community Kitchen rebuild after COVID-19!

I will be sleeping outside in the cold in just a sleeping bag and the clothes on my back. For those who know I have CFS, will also know that this will be especially challenging for me physically and mentally.

I hope to raise a minimum of £50 for this inspiring organisation. At this day and age, no one should have to resort to homelessness but the harsh reality is, it could happen to anyone.

Title: The Storm Fitness 15km Prowler Push

Description: Food is a language the crosses all borders. And for the past five years or more, the Refugee Community Kitchen has done incredible work in the camps in Northern France just the other side of the Channel, providing food in incredibly difficult circumstances for displaced people. (I am proud that many of my family have volunteered there; the project was started and is run by Sam Jones, a schoolfriend of my stepson Karim, and his brilliant wife Paola Gallardo. As they put it, 'We are volunteers. We chop. We stir. We serve. We believe food is a human right. Everyone deserves food that we’d be happy to eat at our own tables.' Since launching, they have served over 2.9 million meals and won a well-deserved Observer Food Monthly Award last year. It's easy to forget right now that ALL charities need our support at this very difficult time, and I am always proud to help these guys. Thanks for donating, if you do...

Title: Tiffany's letting a student cut my hair for charity

CharityName: Refugee Community Kitchen - Prism the Gift Fund
Description:
Greetings family 😊


To celebrate my solar return, I will be volunteering in Calais with RCK to be of service to our displaced brothers and sisters on the border. In 2015, Refugee Community kitchen set up in Calais in response to the humanitarian crisis on our doorstep. You may not see it in the news anymore but there are still vulnerable people living in camps that rely on this service for their daily meals. 


I make this request with love. Minimum donation accepted is £2. If you're struggling to decide on a gift for me then this will be the ideal present! Your gift will go towards purchasing equipment, spices and food ingredients to provide nourishing hot meals. There is no divide between those who serve and those who receive, there is just compassion. Food is a language that crosses all borders ♥️ 


If you're unable to support this cause financially then please consider giving your time. Now in 2019, Refugee Community Kitchen has expanded their work to supporting refugees and others experiencing food poverty right here in London, UK. This is done with a smile through their outreach kitchens in Camden, Hackney, Bethnal Green, and Brixton. They collectively provide over 2000 meals per month and always welcoming more volunteers. Get in touch via refugeecommunitykitchen@gmail.com.


Sending peace, love and blessings your way. A big thank you in advance. 


Sophia Myambala 🌼

(For more information please visit http://www.refugeecommunitykitchen.com/)

They are part of an ongoing recycling project.  I am definitely not a qualified seamstress but enjoy the process of creating. I have various fabrics but if you have loved old shirts (good ply cotton only) that you would like transferring into a few new face masks, please send them to me with a note.

This is a not for profit project but instead I am asking for a donation to Marie Curie.  We were lucky enough to have had their support during the final stages of my fathers life.  They came like angels in our hour of need and made the end of his life at home as comfortable and as dignified as possible.  As a family, we will always be very grateful.

Title: Angela's Colombian Kitchen raising money for much needed support for new mums

Description:
There is a circulatory post going around social media where someone posts that they dress up as a unicorn and dance around their kitchen. Then anyone who reacts to that post is sent a message telling them that they fell for it and that the idea is to spread awareness about breast cancer. They are then instructed to post the same thing on their wall in order to keep it spreading. 

This was great for spreading awareness but I saw no link to any benefit to sufferers or charities. So I've decided to do what the post says. I will dress up as a unicorn, cover myself in glitter and dance around my kitchen for you...but only if we can raise some actual funds to support those suffering from the disease. 

So if you want me to make an embarrassment of myself and give some cash to a good cause please donate!

Description:
When my family and I visited Zanzibar last year, I met an amazing group of children, who don't have anything other than the smiles on their faces!  I want to switch my birthday presents this year to help raise money to set up a Saturday food kitchen for the towns poorest 100 children.  They need £278 to buy the basic equipment   Instead of birthday presents this year I would love to raise money to help buy the basic equipment.  

**It costs £241 per month to keep it running, so if anyone can spare a small monthly donation then please let my mum know!

A little more about it:

The vision: To make a life changing difference to poor and vulnerable children living in Zanzibar, striving to meet their physical, educational, spiritual and social needs, to help them reach their full potential and become educated, independent young adults who know their self-worth. 

The starting point: Our aim is to start small and build from there. We want to begin by addressing the physical need of food by starting a Saturday Feeding project, initially for 40-60 of the most vulnerable children, rising to 100 kids in the Jambiani area.

To begin with we will rely upon a small group of volunteers, led by Clalence to identify the most needy children, and to deliver the Saturday Club.

As well as the provision of food, the Saturday Club will also begin to meet the social needs of children by providing group activities such as acrobatics and street dancing. 

About my friend Clalence:

Clalence was the very first child we helped in Iringa in 2007!
He lived on and off the streets for many years, but thanks in part to the love and help he received from FISCH, he not only survived but became a man with a heart for helping others in need.In the past few years Clalence set up Move Zanzibar, a non-profit organisation whose vision is to move, educate and motivate the young generation of Zanzibar. The plan is for Move Zanzibar to become a project of FISCH, so we can work together to make a difference for the most vulnerable children in Zanzibar.

FISCH always aim to have a direct impact on the needs of the most
vulnerable children.  There long-term aim is for these children to become self-sufficient, balanced, well rounded and valuable members of the community.
Title: Sebastian Goodall's Birthday

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page

Sadly we found out recently one of our valued customers,passed away.

In memory of Debra Holmes,who sadly lost her fight against breast cancer recently.

Debra had a real zest for life,and loved the period in which we concentrate our restorations on, the 1950s.

A school teacher for 40 years who had influenced many a young mind,also a member of Macmillan for years raising funds herself.

She had a large circle of friends and loving family. 

I suggested it maybe a lovely idea to run a draw to win Debra's prized pieces of furniture,that she loved so much,which her friends and family have kindly agreed too.

So that's the idea.These pieces have all been previously restored by us,at Resto-Worx.

These are namely a rare and much sought after Maidsaver kitchen larder,with beautiful sun ray glass.

A Remploy folding tea trolley on castors and a Fleetwood double wall cupboard with raindrop glass sliding doors.

3 beautiful functional pieces.

We are asking for a minimum donation of £5,but please give as much as you can afford for this worthy cause.

Someone will win these wonderful pieces.Please bear in mind these pieces are not new and although restored will have wear commensurate with useage.

We have also arranged free Uk delivery,some restrictions may apply on geographic area.

Please go to www.facebook.com/Resto-Worx for full details on the draw.
Title: Resto-worx Fundraiser

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Words can't express how thankful I am for YouthLine's support.
I am so grateful for them pairing me up with the most kind and caring counsellor, Sue. The support she provided me with over the last few years has made such an impact on my life.

Baking is something I am passionate about, however when I am feeling numb, it can be very hard to motivate myself to do the things I love. Sue reminded me that baking can be a creative outlet and it can also occupy my mind, allowing me to feel more like myself.

So with that in mind I am going to be whisking my way around the kitchen every week, following along with bake off and providing the Staff at my workplace with the tasty bakes. 

Setting this challenge allows me to focus on something once a week, pushing myself to carry on and do something I love, as well as raising money for a special charity.

As YouthLine is a free service, I would like to show my love and appreciation for them, whilst also spreading the word about what they have to offer and breaking the stigma around discussing mental health!

Youthline provides a FREE, confidential counselling service for young people attending secondary school and adults who care for and support young people.

Title: Eddie's Ed's March for Ukraine

Description:
Welcome to our page!

If there are three things that H and Ed possess in life... it's ambition, stupidity and legs with appetite. If you also happen to have these qualities, feel free to join us on an epic challenge!

Everyone around the country has been shocked by the situation in Ukraine, and we can only imagine how terrifying and distressing it must be for citizens caught up in the conflict, constantly in fear for their lives and watching their livelihood around them being destroyed.

World Central Kitchen provides incredible relief for people in humanitarian crises by delivering nourishing meals in the most desperate of times. When all you've got are the clothes in your backpack and your exhausted and hungry with nowhere to go, a warm bowl of soup or a nutritious curry can make all the difference to your day. The WCK have already set up numerous operations across Ukrainian cities and in country where refugees have fled, and they continue to provide food for those in need all over the world.

To help fundraise, Ed and I have created our 100 miles in 48 hours event, and you're invited! Starting from Cheltenham, together we will all be walking a 10 mile loop, followed by 6 x 15 mile loops, briefly resting at my house during the interim. The date of the walk is 2nd-4th June 2022, which takes place over the Queen's Jubilee period. You're welcome to join us for as much or as little of the walk as you feel comfortable with! If you are considering joining us, please check out the YouTube video below for more details:

Every penny of donations helps toward somebody in need getting that hot meal.

Thank you for all your love and support,

H and Ed.
Title: H's March For Ukraine

Description:
Hello friends, 

You may have heard a lot of chat over the past few months… Calories, lycra, heart rate zones. All riveting stuff!

On the 29th May I will be putting myself through the ringer with a half Ironman. 6 months ago I could barely muster a 10km run, so don’t worry, this will be big and nasty.

I’m returning to the mother land Canada, for my first Triathlon race and I’ll be raising funds for World Central Kitchen (WCK)  to support their efforts in Ukraine and beyond. 

I was recommend the charity from my good pal Symo, who recently returned from an immense aid trip to the Ukrainian border. This got me fired-up to combine this Ironman challenge with some fundraising! 

Every donation will help - thanks in advance and I’ll keep you all posted on my progress! 

Last weeks statement from WCK:

“The invasion of Ukraine has now entered its third month, and WCK continues to expand our efforts to support the brave and resilient Ukrainian people. Millions of families have been forced to flee their homes as other live in basements underground, staying safe as bombs fall on their neighborhoods. The attacks have not slowed, and as the war shifts east and south, WCK teams are delivering meals to newly liberated cities and stockpiling food in areas under constant attack”

Description:
Alzheimer’s Society is transforming the landscape of dementia forever. Until the day a cure is found,  they create a society where those affected by dementia are supported and accepted, able to live in their community without fear or prejudice. 

At Margaret’s Cottage and Mrs. C’s Home Kitchen, we have put our creative, culinary heads together to raise some much-needed cash for the Alzheimer’s Society.

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common form of dementia and it touches so many families, including our own. We want to support the Alzheimer’s Society because it funds research into the cause, cure, care and prevention of dementia. Alzheimer’s and other forms of dementia do not just involve memory loss. Dementia is a terminal
disease of the brain that affects difficulties with thinking, problem-solving, confidence, ability and language.

We [Sharon and Ciara] will spend days donating our time,  our energy and  our skills into producing some of your favourite delicious treats, so you can pre-order and then purchase and collect your items on Saturday 22nd of May at the Alzheimer's [virtual] Bake Sale.

We'd love you to donate , if you cannot support our Bake Sale.

Or donate AND order some of our cakes. Your donation might even off-set your calories! Well, it's worth a try.
Title: Mrs. C's Home Kitchen & Margaret's Cottage B&B-Bake Sale for Alzheimer's

Description:
